It represents the probability that the test will correctly reject a false null hypothesis, meaning it shows how likely your test is to find a real difference or relationship in your data. The closer power is to 100%, the better and more reliable your test becomes at identifying true effects.

title: volume
content: Volume refers to the amount of data in a dataset, usually measured in bytes, kilobytes (KB), megabytes (MB), gigabytes (GB), terabytes (TB), or larger units. It helps determine storage and processing resources needed, as well as the potential impact on analysis time and performance in data analytics.

title: sentiment analysis
content: Sentiment Analysis is a method in data analysis that finds and extracts feelings, opinions, or attitudes from written content. It involves categorizing the sentiment of a text as positive, negative, or neutral, helping to understand public opinion, brand perception, and more.

title: mam
content: Mam (short for "Market Adjusted Margin") is a way to measure the profitability of a product or service by comparing its revenue with costs, after considering market changes like demand, competition, and pricing. It helps businesses make informed decisions in financial analysis.

title: correlation analysis
content: Correlation analysis is a method that measures how much two variables affect each other and whether they have a pattern or trend. It uses a number called the "correlation coefficient" to show the strength and direction of their connection, ranging from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to 1 (perfect positive correlation), with 0 meaning no relationship.

title: alpha risk
content: Alpha risk, also called idiosyncratic or specific risk, is the uncertainty linked to an individual investment's return due to factors unique to that asset. It represents potential losses from unexpected events unrelated to market-wide fluctuations. In data analytics, alpha risk helps quantify how company-specific risks affect a security's performance and can be used in portfolio management strategies to diversify investments and minimize overall risk exposure.

title: data governance
content: Data governance is a system of rules and procedures that ensure an organization handles its data correctly, securely, and accurately. It involves assigning roles for data stewards, setting guidelines for using data, and using technology to monitor and enforce these rules. By doing this well, organizations can make better decisions based on reliable information.

title: ticketsysteme
content: Ticket systems are software programs that help manage and track support requests or issues submitted by users. They allow organizations to efficiently handle customer queries, bugs, or complaints by assigning them as tickets with unique identifiers. Data Analytics professionals can analyze ticket system data to identify trends, find areas for improvement, and optimize customer service processes.

title: fit
content: In data analytics, "fit" means adjusting and optimizing an analytical model or algorithm to better match the actual data. This involves choosing suitable parameters and fine-tuning them to minimize errors or maximize performance metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, or F1 score. The aim is to create a well-fitting model that can effectively predict, classify, or summarize the underlying patterns in the data.

title: high performance computing
content: High Performance Computing (HPC) is using powerful computer systems, like supercomputers, to solve complex problems that regular computers can't handle quickly enough. In data analytics, HPC speeds up processing and analysis of large datasets by dividing tasks among many processors, leading to faster insights and better decision-making processes.

title: test statistic
content: A test statistic is a number calculated from sample data that helps determine if observed results match a specific hypothesis or model. It's used in statistical tests to decide whether there's enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis (a default assumption) for an alternative one. The test statistic is derived using formulas and compared to a critical value (like those found in distribution tables) to make decisions about the validity of the hypothesis.

title: da
content: Data Analysis (Da) is the process of studying raw data to find useful patterns, trends, or insights. It involves organizing, cleaning, and transforming data into a format that can be easily analyzed using statistics and visual tools. The main goal is to help with decision-making by providing valuable information about the underlying data.

title: anova table
content: An ANOVA table is a statistical tool that helps compare the means of multiple groups or categories in data analysis. It determines if there are significant differences between these groups while considering their variability within each group. The table shows sums of squares for factors being compared and their interaction, along with degrees of freedom, mean square, and F-statistic. By analyzing the F-statistic and its p-value, researchers can decide if there are significant differences among the groups.

title: distributed file system
content: A distributed file system is a way to store and manage data across multiple servers or nodes in a network. It allows efficient scaling by dividing the work among different machines, ensuring high availability, fault tolerance, and better performance. Each node holds part of the overall data, so clients can access files from any node, making it seem like all data is stored on one system. This design is especially helpful for large-scale data processing tasks in Data Analytics, where handling vast amounts of data efficiently becomes crucial.

title: optimization analysis
content: Optimization Analysis is the process of finding the best way to improve a system or process by comparing different options and choosing the most suitable one based on specific goals and limitations. It uses techniques like mathematical modeling, statistical analysis, and heuristic methods to find optimal solutions that maximize efficiency, minimize costs, or achieve other desired outcomes. This field is especially important in data analytics, as it helps organizations make informed decisions by effectively using their data.

title: population
content: In data analytics, "population" means all individual items (like people, objects, events) that are being studied. These can be any measurable things. We often look at smaller groups called "samples" to understand the bigger group and make decisions or find patterns in the data.

title: data scientist
content: A data scientist is a professional who uses advanced techniques to find useful information from large, complex sets of data. They combine skills in math, computer programming, and knowledge about specific fields to identify patterns, make predictions, and improve decision-making for organizations. Their work includes cleaning up data, creating new ways to look at the data (feature engineering), building models, and sharing their findings with others who need to know.

title: machine learning
content: Machine Learning is the process of teaching computer algorithms to learn from data and make predictions or decisions without explicit programming. It uses methods like supervised learning (learning from labeled data), unsupervised learning (finding patterns in unlabeled data), and reinforcement learning (learning through trial-and-error interactions). The aim is for machines to improve at a specific task over time, without being explicitly programmed.

title: multi-dimensional databases
content: A multi-dimensional database is a system that stores, organizes, and analyzes complex datasets with various interconnected variables (like time, location, categories). It helps users efficiently explore and visualize data by allowing them to slice, dice, and pivot it along different dimensions, providing insights for decision-making in fields like business intelligence and data analytics.

title: event
content: An event in data analytics is a specific action or occurrence recorded within a dataset. It's a measurable instance that helps understand phenomena or processes. Examples include user interactions, transactions, system triggers, and other activities generating data points. By analyzing these events, analysts can find patterns, trends, and insights for decision-making.

title: data feed
content: A data feed is a continuous flow of regularly updated information that various apps or systems can access for real-time or near-real-time use. It helps users monitor trends, detect anomalies, and make informed decisions based on the latest insights in data analytics.

title: comparative analysis
content: Comparative Analysis is a technique in data analysis that looks at two or more things, sets of data, or variables to find similarities, differences, and patterns between them. It helps understand relationships, trends, and variations among the compared elements, leading to better decisions and problem-solving. This process often involves visualizations, statistical tests, and data manipulation techniques to draw meaningful insights from comparisons.

title: predictive modelling
content: Predictive modeling is a method in data analytics that creates mathematical models to forecast future outcomes using past patterns. It identifies connections between different inputs (independent variables) and an output (dependent variable), enabling predictions about the dependent variable's future values with new input values. This helps businesses make better decisions, streamline processes, and enhance overall performance.

title: batch processing
content: Batch processing means handling big amounts of data in groups instead of individually or in real-time. This method is often used with huge datasets that need a lot of computer power. Each group is processed one after another, and the results are usually saved for further study or action. Processing data this way can be more efficient for large datasets because it helps use resources better and can reduce waiting time.

title: r
content: R is a free, open-source programming language and environment designed for statistical computing and graphics. It has many tools and libraries for data manipulation, analysis, and visualization, making it popular among data analysts and researchers. With its strong community support and active development, R provides an accessible platform for learning and applying data analytics techniques.

title: dwh
content: A Data Warehouse (DWH) is a large storage of combined, changing over time, and stable data that helps managers make decisions by showing past, current, and future views of business activities. It gathers data from various sources, changes it into one format, and keeps it for analysis and querying. DWH is the base for Business Intelligence (BI) tools and plays a vital role in data-driven decision making.

title: demographic data
content: Demographic data is information about a population's characteristics, such as age, gender, race, income, education level, occupation, and marital status. It helps categorize individuals for analysis and decision-making in fields like marketing, politics, and urban planning.

title: unstructured data
content: Unstructured data refers to information that doesn't follow a predefined format or model. It includes various types of raw, free-form data such as text from social media posts, emails, and surveys; images, audio, and video files; and sensor data. Unlike structured data, which is organized in tables or databases, unstructured data requires advanced techniques like natural language processing and machine learning to extract meaningful insights.

title: data as a service (daas)
content: Data as a Service (DaaS) is a cloud-based service that lets users access and use real-time data from various sources. It simplifies handling large datasets by providing a centralized, scalable solution easily integrated into existing systems. DaaS providers offer customizable subscriptions so clients can choose specific datasets for their needs.

title: probability
content: Probability is how likely something is to happen from all possible outcomes in data analytics. It shows the frequency of an outcome in many trials and is a number between 0 (impossible) and 1 (certain).

title: dashboard
content: A dashboard is a clear, interactive display of important data and key metrics, making it easy to monitor, analyze, and make decisions based on real-time or near-real-time information from various sources. It's commonly used in business intelligence, system performance monitoring, and tracking progress towards goals.

title: query
content: A query in data analytics is a specific question asked to a dataset using structured language or programming syntax. It helps users extract, filter, or analyze large amounts of data, leading to insights and decision-making. For example, a user might write a SQL query to find the average age of customers who bought a certain product.

title: discrete data
content: Discrete data are numbers that are separate and distinct from each other, usually whole numbers like 1, 2, 3, etc. Unlike continuous data which can have any value within a range, discrete data has only a limited number of possible values. Examples include the number of children in a family, items bought, or different species observed in an ecosystem.

title: aggregation
content: Aggregation in data analytics is the process of combining many individual data points into simpler, summarized values like counts, averages, or sums. This simplifies large datasets for easier analysis and visualization, helping us find insights from complex information.

title: massively parallel processing (mpp)
content: Massively Parallel Processing (MPP) is a method where many processing units work together on different parts of a big dataset to solve complex problems faster. In data analytics, MPP systems divide the data across multiple nodes and process them at once, which speeds up query execution and improves performance when dealing with large datasets.

title: semi-structured data
content: Semi-structured data is information that has some organization but isn't strictly formatted like a spreadsheet or database. It often appears in XML, JSON, or HTML formats and contains both structured and unstructured parts. This type of data can be easier to process than fully unstructured data, but still needs specialized techniques to extract useful insights.

title: probability distribution
content: A probability distribution is a way to describe the chances of different outcomes in random events or data sets. It assigns numbers (probabilities) to each outcome, making sure all probabilities add up to 1. This shows how likely each event can happen. Common types are uniform, normal, and binomial distributions.

title: latency
content: Latency means how long it takes for a system or network to respond after receiving a request or action. In data analytics, this can affect the speed of processing and analyzing data, which in turn influences the efficiency of insights gained from that data. To make real-time decisions based on current information, it's important to minimize latency.

title: visualization
content: Visualization is turning data into clear, visually appealing graphics like charts, graphs, or diagrams (like bar charts, scatter plots, or heat maps) to make it easier to understand and interpret. It helps find patterns, trends, and connections in the data, which aids better decision-making and sharing insights.

title: normal distribution
content: A normal distribution, also called Gaussian or bell curve, is a pattern that shows how often different values appear in a set of data. It has two important parts: the mean (average) and standard deviation. Most numbers are close to the average, while fewer numbers are far away. The shape of this pattern is symmetrical and looks like a bell, which makes it common in many natural events and statistical studies.

title: data mining
content: Data mining is about finding patterns, connections, or knowledge in large amounts of data using methods like machine learning algorithms, statistical analysis, and visualization tools. It involves getting valuable information from complex sources, often to make predictions or spot trends that can guide decision-making processes.

title: data maturity
content: Data maturity is how well an organization handles its data - from collecting and managing it to analyzing and using it effectively. It involves the processes, tools, and skills needed to turn raw data into useful insights that guide better decisions. As organizations grow in their data maturity, they become more skilled at using their data resources, leading to better business results.

title: metadata
content: Metadata is information about other data or sets of data. It's like "data about data" and can include details such as who created it, when it was made, its purpose, format, and connections to other datasets. In Data Analytics, this helps us better understand, organize, and manage our data by providing important context and background information.

title: references
content: In data analytics, references mean where a piece of data comes from, like surveys, databases, or other studies. They are important for being honest and trustworthy, so analysts can check if their findings are correct and give credit to the original sources.

title: algorithm
content: An algorithm is a clear set of instructions to solve problems or complete tasks. In data analytics, algorithms are used with large datasets to process, analyze, and extract insights. They can be mathematical formulas, decision trees, or machine learning models that transform raw data into meaningful information. Algorithms help identify patterns, make predictions, and optimize decisions based on the available data.

title: data cleansing
content: Data cleansing is the process of fixing incorrect, inconsistent, or missing information within a dataset. It involves removing or correcting errors, standardizing formats, and ensuring all entries are complete and relevant for analysis. This improves data quality and reliability, leading to more accurate insights and better decision-making.

title: one sample t-test
content: A one-sample t-test is a statistical test used to check if the average of a single group is significantly different from a known or expected overall average. It compares the actual sample average with the idea that the true population average equals a specific value, usually zero. The test uses the t-statistic, which measures how much the sample average differs from the assumed average, considering the variability in the sample. If the calculated t-value is significantly different from zero, it suggests that the null hypothesis can be rejected, meaning the true population average likely differs from the assumed value.

title: dark data
content: Dark data is information within an organization that goes unused because it's not well categorized, hard to access, or simply overlooked. This untapped data could provide valuable insights for better decisions if properly analyzed and used.

title: f-test
content: An F-test is a statistical test that helps compare variances or slopes between two groups in regression analysis or checks if multiple independent variables significantly impact the dependent variable in a multiple linear regression model. It does this by comparing the ratio of two variance estimates, with larger values indicating significant differences between the groups.

title: nosql (not only sql)
content: NOSQL databases are a type of system that offers an alternative to traditional SQL (Structured Query Language) databases, providing more flexibility and scalability. Unlike SQL databases which primarily store structured data in tables, NOSQL databases can handle various unstructured data types like documents, graphs, or key-value pairs. They allow for greater freedom in designing data models and easily scale to manage large amounts of data without affecting performance.

title: location analytics
content: Location analytics is the process of gathering, examining, and visualizing geographical data to discover insights about human behavior, patterns, and trends in specific locations. It involves using various statistical and machine learning techniques to find connections between location-based data and other relevant factors, which helps businesses make informed decisions based on spatial information.

title: dms
content: A Data Management System (DMS) is a software or platform that efficiently handles large amounts of data by collecting, storing, processing, and analyzing it. It ensures data integrity, security, and consistency while making it easy to access and retrieve for various purposes like decision-making, reporting, and analysis.

title: saas
content: SaaS (Software as a Service) is a way of delivering software over the internet on a subscription basis. In data analytics, it means businesses can use powerful tools without installing or maintaining physical infrastructure themselves. They just pay for the service and access it through their web browser or other devices. This model offers easy scalability, frequent updates, and cost-effective access to advanced technologies.

title: anomaly detection
content: Anomaly Detection is the process of finding unusual or unexpected patterns, values, or events in a dataset that significantly differ from normal occurrences. It involves analyzing data to detect outliers, which can provide valuable insights for businesses and researchers. By comparing new observations with past trends, anomalies can be identified and further investigated. This technique is particularly useful in fraud detection, predictive maintenance, and intrusion detection systems.

title: alternative hypothesis (ha)
content: In data analytics, the alternative hypothesis (Ha) is the statement that suggests an effect or relationship exists between variables in a dataset. It contradicts or challenges the null hypothesis (H0), which assumes no such effect or relationship. The alternative hypothesis helps determine if there's enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative one.

title: ai
content: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is about creating computer systems that can do things usually done by humans, such as learning, problem-solving, seeing, and decision-making. In data analysis, AI methods like machine learning algorithms let computers look at lots of information, find patterns, make predictions, and get better without being told exactly how to do it.

title: data science
content: Data Science is a field that combines skills from math, stats, computer science, and domain knowledge to find insights and knowledge in both organized and unorganized data. It includes tasks like cleaning, analyzing, modeling, and visualizing data to help organizations make smart decisions based on evidence found in the data.

title: range
content: Range in data analytics is the collection of all possible values a variable can have within a specific context. It can be shown as a continuous range (for continuous variables) or a list of distinct values (for categorical or discrete variables). In simpler words, it's the range of numbers or categories a particular data point might belong to.

title: cluster computing
content: Cluster computing is when many connected computers work together as one system to solve complex problems or process large amounts of data more efficiently than a single computer could alone. Each computer (or node) does specific parts of the task, and their combined resources are managed by special software. This way, you get increased power, faster processing times, and better scalability for big data tasks.

title: exploratory analysis
content: Exploratory Analysis is the first step in examining your data to discover insights, identify patterns, and reveal connections between different elements. It includes activities like cleaning up the data, calculating basic statistics, and creating visualizations to better comprehend it before moving on to more formal statistical analyses or constructing predictive models. This process helps detect potential issues with the data, understand its structure, and pinpoint which variables are most important for further study.

title: neural network
content: A neural network is a computer model that mimics the brain's neurons. It has layers of connected nodes (artificial neurons) that process and share information using connections called edges or weights. These networks can learn from data, identify patterns, and make predictions by adjusting their internal links based on input-output examples. In data analysis, neural networks are used for tasks like classification, regression, and natural language processing.

title: empirical model
content: An empirical model is a formula created from real-world data to describe, predict, or explain phenomena. It's based on evidence gathered through experiments, observations, or statistics. In Data Analytics, it helps us understand relationships between variables and make informed decisions using the patterns found in the data.

title: cloud
content: A "cloud" in data analytics means a group of distant computers owned by companies that let people store, organize, and analyze big sets of information over the internet. It offers flexible, cost-effective, and scalable ways to handle large amounts of data without needing lots of on-site equipment.

title: in-memory computing
content: In-memory computing is a method that processes data directly within the computer's memory (RAM) instead of reading it from slower storage devices like hard drives or solid-state drives. This speeds up data access and manipulation, making it ideal for real-time analytics and big data applications where fast response times are crucial. By keeping data in RAM, in-memory computing reduces input/output operations, which can be slow and delay processing.

title: acid test
content: The Acid Test, also called the Current Ratio, is a way to check how well a company can quickly cover its short-term debts. It does this by comparing what it has that can be easily turned into cash (like money in the bank, things it sells, and money people owe it) with what it owes within the next year. A higher Acid Test value means the company is better at paying off its immediate debt using its most liquid resources.

title: artificial intelligence
content: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is about creating computer systems that can do things usually done by humans, like learning, problem-solving, seeing, and decision-making. It uses methods such as machine learning, understanding language, and robotics to let machines learn from data, adjust to new situations, and interact with people more naturally.

title: pareto chart
content: A Pareto Chart is a visual tool in data analysis that helps compare and represent different categories within a dataset by their frequency or magnitude. It arranges the categories in descending order, starting with the most frequent or significant category on the left. This allows you to quickly identify the main contributors to an issue or process. The chart is named after the Pareto Principle, also known as the 80/20 rule, which suggests that 80% of consequences come from just 20% of causes.

title: Bar chart
content: A bar chart is a simple way to show numbers from groups (categories) using rectangles of different heights or lengths. It helps you easily compare the amounts between these groups by just looking at the chart. In data analysis, it often shows trends and patterns in the data.

title: Line chart
content: A line chart is a clear way to show data on a flat surface with two lines (x and y). The x-axis shows time or categories, while the y-axis shows values. Each point in your data gets placed on this grid. Then, we draw lines between these points to see how things change over time or among different groups. It's great for showing changes in things like stock prices, weather, and sales.

title: Pie chart
content: A pie chart is a circle graph that shows different parts of a dataset, where each slice represents a category. The size of each slice shows how big or small that category is compared to the whole data. It helps us see the distribution of categories in an easy and clear way.

title: Scatter plot
content: A scatter plot is a simple graph that shows how two things are related. It does this by putting one thing on the horizontal line (x-axis) and another on the vertical line (y-axis). Each dot on the graph represents a piece of data, helping you see if there's any pattern or connection between those two things just by looking at it.

title: Histogram
content: A histogram is a chart showing how often different values appear in a set of data, using bars where height represents frequency within specific ranges (or "bins"). It helps visualize the shape and spread of the data, making it easier to spot patterns and trends for further analysis.

title: Area chart
content: An area chart is a graphical way to show data in data analytics, using filled areas between lines or curves. It helps visualize changes over time or compare categories by showing both the size and trend of the data. Each area on the chart represents a specific category or time period, making it easy to compare values and see patterns.

title: Bubble chart
content: A bubble chart is a graphical tool in data analytics that shows three aspects of data - value, category, and magnitude - using circles (or "bubbles") with different sizes, colors, and positions. The size of each circle represents the magnitude of the data point, its color indicates the category, and its position on the x-y plane signifies the value. This visualization method helps quickly spot trends, patterns, and outliers in multidimensional datasets.

title: Radar chart
content: A radar chart, also called a spider or star plot, is a graph that shows multiple factors (or features) of individual data points in a two-dimensional space. It looks like a polygon with several equally spaced arms radiating from the center, where each arm represents one factor being measured. The length of each arm shows the value of that factor for the given data point, allowing you to compare and analyze the strengths or weaknesses across all factors at once.

title: Heatmap
content: A heatmap is a colored grid that shows data values. It uses colors to highlight areas with more data, making it easier to see patterns and trends. In data analytics, heatmaps can help visualize relationships between variables, analyze groupings, and compare distributions across categories.

title: Box plot
content: A box plot is a simple graph that shows important statistics about a set of data. It displays the middle value (median), the values at 25th and 75th percentiles (quartiles), and any unusual values (outliers) in one clear picture. The box itself goes from the first quartile to the third quartile, with a line inside it showing the median. Lines called "whiskers" extend from each end of the box, reaching down to the smallest and largest values within 1.5 times the range between the quartiles (interquartile range). Any data points beyond these whiskers are considered outliers and are plotted separately. Box plots help us see the shape of the data distribution, its central tendency, and how spread out it is while identifying any unusual values.

title: Waterfall chart
content: A Waterfall Chart is a simple graph that shows how a single value changes over time or across categories through a series of cumulative calculations. It uses a horizontal bar divided into sections, where each section represents a specific change, and the total sum is shown at the end. This chart helps visualize progress, identify trends, and highlight variances in data analysis by showing how an initial value evolves through additions, subtractions, or other transformations.

title: Treemap
content: A treemap is a visual way to show hierarchical data using rectangles, where each rectangle represents a category or item in your data. The size of each rectangle shows how much there is of that category, making it easy to compare them. Treemaps are helpful for understanding patterns and trends when dealing with complex data.

title: Funnel chart
content: A funnel chart is a visual tool that shows a step-by-step process or sales pipeline. Each step's width represents the number of people at that stage. It helps you see how many start and how they progress, showing where things get tougher (narrow part) or more people are involved (wide part).

title: Doughnut chart
content: A doughnut chart is a circular graph that shows data in a donut-shaped layout. It has an outer ring and one or more inner rings, with each section representing a specific category or value within the dataset. The size and color of each segment can be customized to represent different variables, making it useful for comparing proportions or percentages visually.

title: Candlestick chart
content: A Candlestick chart is a clear graphical display of price changes in financial markets, like stocks or commodities. It shows the opening, closing, highest, and lowest prices for each time period (like a day or hour). The body of the candlestick represents the difference between the opening and closing prices, with a solid color if the closing price is higher and hollow if it's lower. Thin lines above and below the body are called "shadows" or "wicks," showing the highest and lowest prices reached during that period. Candlestick charts help you see market trends and find possible trading opportunities.

title: discounting (in financial context)
content: In finance, "discounting" means estimating the current worth (present value) of money you'll receive in the future. This is because money today can be invested and grow over time, making it more valuable than the same amount received later. The formula for this calculation is: PV = CF / (1 + r)^n, where PV is the present value, CF is the future cash flow, r is the discount rate, and n is the number of periods until you receive the money.

title: report distribution
content: Report Distribution is the process of sharing business intelligence reports with important people within an organization. This involves choosing the best ways (like email, shared folders, or special software) and formats (such as PDFs, spreadsheets, or interactive dashboards), to make sure everyone gets the right information on time so they can make smart decisions.

title: waterfall model (waterfall)
content: The Waterfall Model is a traditional, step-by-step approach to software development, including Business Intelligence (BI) projects. It involves sequential stages: gathering requirements, analysis, design, implementation, testing, deployment, and maintenance. Each stage builds upon the previous one, with feedback loops allowing for adjustments as needed.

title: key performance indicator (kpi)
content: A Key Performance Indicator (KPI) is a clear, measurable value that helps evaluate an organization's success in reaching its strategic targets. It offers useful insights into the effectiveness of business strategies, processes, and initiatives by focusing on specific performance aspects. KPIs are used to track progress towards organizational goals and can be applied across various departments within a company.

title: field transformation
content: Field transformation means altering or adjusting information within specific columns (fields) of a dataset. This can involve tasks like changing data types, combining values, doing calculations, or applying rules to clean and organize data before using it in Business Intelligence tools. It helps make sure the data is consistent, correct, and useful for finding insights.

title: inmom approach
content: The Inmon Approach is a method to design and build Business Intelligence (BI) systems. It focuses on organizing data based on the company's understanding of its operations rather than technical aspects like storage or processing. This involves creating a central, subject-focused data warehouse that serves as a single source of truth for all business information. By structuring data this way, organizations can better analyze and report their performance, leading to improved decision-making.

title: proof of concept
content: A "Proof of Concept" (PoC) in Business Intelligence is a simple demonstration or prototype that shows an idea works and has potential value. It helps decide if a proposed solution, technology, or approach is worth investing more resources into by testing it on a small scale first. This usually involves creating a basic version to see how well it functions, performs, and meets the needs of stakeholders.

title: fmea (failure mode and effects analysis)
content: FMEA, short for Failure Mode and Effects Analysis, is a method that helps identify possible failures in processes, products, or systems, evaluate their seriousness, and decide on actions to prevent or reduce them. It's a useful tool for managing risks in business intelligence, allowing companies to foresee problems before they happen and make informed choices to enhance performance and minimize negative effects.

title: business analytics (ba)
content: Business Analytics (BA) is the process of analyzing data from various sources to find patterns, trends, and useful information for organizations. This involves collecting, processing, and examining large amounts of data using math and statistics, along with advanced techniques like predictive modeling, machine learning, and data visualization. The aim is to provide insights that help in strategic planning, improve efficiency, and boost overall business performance.

title: waterfall chart
content: A waterfall chart is a graph that shows how values change over time or across different categories by stacking horizontal bars. Each bar represents a stage or category, and the height of each bar shows its value. The next bar's height is based on adding or subtracting the previous bar's value, creating a cascading effect. This chart is helpful in business intelligence to track budgets, resource allocation, and other cumulative processes.

title: sunburst chart
content: A sunburst chart is an interactive tool for visualizing hierarchical data in a tree-like, radial structure. It helps users explore and analyze multi-level categorical data by expanding or collapsing branches to reveal relationships between different levels of information.

title: human resources dashboard (hr dashboard)
content: A Human Resources (HR) Dashboard is a helpful tool that shows important HR data in one easy-to-use platform. It gives you real-time information about employee performance, hiring, keeping employees, and other HR tasks. By showing this info in an easy-to-understand graphical format, it helps managers make better decisions for their company's people.

title: histogram
content: A histogram is a chart that shows how often data falls within different ranges (or groups). It helps you see the distribution of data in things like sales revenue or ages of customers. In business, it's useful for finding patterns, trends, and unusual values.

title: scorecard
content: A scorecard is a visual tool that shows important measurements (KPIs) and goals for a company or department. It gives a quick look at the current situation, trends, and targets for different metrics, helping people in charge see how things are going, find ways to improve, and make smart choices.

title: visual studio
content: Visual Studio is a powerful all-in-one tool for software development called an IDE (Integrated Development Environment). It helps developers create various types of apps, including those related to business intelligence. It offers tools for coding, debugging, testing, and deploying software in languages like C#, VB.NET, and Python. In the context of Business Intelligence, it can be used to build reporting solutions, data analysis tools, and other BI-related applications.

title: roi
content: ROI (Return On Investment) is a way to measure how well an investment or business decision performs. It's calculated by dividing the profit earned from an investment by the cost of that investment. A higher ROI means better performance and more profits, while a lower ROI suggests less efficient use of resources. In Business Intelligence, understanding and analyzing ROI helps organizations make smart decisions about using their resources and evaluating the success of their strategies.

title: bi application designer
content: A Bi Application Designer is a professional who creates, develops, and implements software specifically for Business Intelligence (BI) tasks. They design user-friendly interfaces for data visualization, analysis, and reporting tools, and integrate these applications with existing business systems to support informed decision-making. They work closely with data analysts, data scientists, and other stakeholders to ensure the applications meet an organization's specific BI needs.

title: microsoft bi stack
content: The Microsoft BI Stack is a set of connected tools and services from Microsoft that help businesses analyze, visualize, and report data efficiently. It includes products like Power BI for data analysis and visualization, SQL Server Analysis Services (SSAS) for advanced analytics, and SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS) for creating reports. These components work well together, enabling organizations to make informed decisions based on their data.

title: extract, transform, load (etl)
content: ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) is a method in handling data that involves getting raw information from different sources, changing it into a uniform format, and putting it into a target system or database for further analysis and reporting. This process helps businesses gather and organize their data, leading to better decision-making using Business Intelligence tools.

title: data warehouse
content: A data warehouse is a big storage place that collects and organizes large amounts of past and current data from different sources within an organization. It helps with Business Intelligence (BI) by giving a clear, combined view of the data, making it easier to make decisions and analyze information. The data in a warehouse is usually well-organized, cleaned up, and set up for easy searching, so people can quickly find and study what they need using tools like SQL queries or reporting software.

title: jet analytics (previously jet enterprise)
content: Jet Analytics is a business intelligence tool that lets organizations gather, examine, and visualize data from multiple sources. It empowers users to create interactive dashboards, reports, and insights, helping departments make informed decisions. With its easy-to-use interface and strong analytics features, Jet Analytics helps businesses gain valuable insights and drive growth.

title: financial reporting
content: Financial Reporting is the process of presenting and sharing a business entity's financial information about its performance, position, and changes in resources over time. This involves creating and distributing financial statements like income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements to stakeholders such as investors, creditors, and regulators. These reports help users evaluate the company's financial health, make informed decisions, and ensure compliance with relevant laws and standards.

title: slowly changing dimensions (scd)
content: Slowly Changing Dimensions (SCD) is a method in data warehousing that handles attribute changes over time within dimensions. It helps preserve historical records of attribute values, enabling businesses to analyze trends and patterns accurately. SCD types include: 1) Type 1 (replace old value with new), 2) Type 2 (keep both old and new values), and 3) Type 3 (combine changes into a single new value).

title: view
content: A "view" in Business Intelligence is a customized display of data from various sources, showing specific information for a particular audience or purpose. It often uses visualizations like charts and tables to help you focus on certain aspects of your data while hiding others.

title: saas
content: SaaS (Software as a Service) is a way of delivering software over the internet on a subscription basis. In simpler terms, it means you access and use software hosted by someone else through the internet, without needing to install it on your own computer or maintain any in-house IT infrastructure. For Business Intelligence, SaaS platforms provide tools for analyzing data, creating visualizations, and generating reports that can be accessed remotely, making it easier for organizations to analyze their data without relying heavily on internal IT resources or expertise.

title: requirements specification and specifications
content: A requirements specification is a thorough document that clearly explains the specific needs, expectations, and desired outcomes for a particular Business Intelligence (BI) system or project. It serves as a guide for developers and stakeholders to understand what features, functionalities, and performance standards are necessary. The requirements specification should be straightforward, concise, and complete so everyone involved has a shared understanding of the project's goals and objectives.

title: lastenheft und pflichtenheft
content:
Lastenheft (German) and Pflichtenheft (German) are tools used in business projects to define requirements and expectations for a product or service. They serve as a blueprint, outlining the scope, objectives, and deliverables of the project. 

Lastenheft specifically refers to the "requirements specification" document, which details the functional and non-functional needs of a project. It includes technical specifications, user requirements, and any constraints or limitations that must be considered during development.

Pflichtenheft, on the other hand, is the "specification sheet" or "task list," which outlines tasks, responsibilities, and deadlines for each team member involved in the project. It ensures clear communication of expectations and helps to maintain accountability throughout the project lifecycle.

title: spider chart
content: A spider chart, also called a radial or web chart, is a graph that shows different variables (or categories) as lines radiating from a central point. Each line's length represents the value of a specific variable, making it easy to compare them in one graphic. It's helpful in Business Intelligence for comparing and analyzing data across various dimensions or categories.

title: jet basics (previously jet express)
content: Jet Basics refers to understanding the fundamental concepts and principles behind a powerful Business Intelligence (BI) tool called "Jet Express". This involves learning how Jet Express handles data extraction, transformation, and loading (ETL) processes; its ability to generate insights from large datasets through querying; and its role in simplifying data visualization and reporting. In essence, it's about mastering the core functions of this specific BI tool to effectively use it within an organization.

title: database administrator (dba)
content: A Database Administrator (DBA) is a professional who takes care of an organization's databases. They make sure the data is safe, correct, and works well by designing good database structures, creating backup plans, and controlling who can access it. In the world of Business Intelligence, DBAs are very important for making sure that data is stored, found, and analyzed properly to help with decision-making.

title: dashboard
content: A dashboard is a clear display of important data and key performance indicators (KPIs) using charts, graphs, or tables. It helps people in businesses easily monitor and analyze vital information, allowing them to make smart decisions and track progress towards their goals.

title: ds
content: In the field of Business Intelligence (BI), 'DS' stands for Data Science - a mix of various disciplines that use scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to find valuable insights and knowledge from both structured and unstructured data. This includes techniques like data mining, machine learning, predictive modeling, and statistical analysis, all aimed at helping businesses make informed decisions.

title: data warehouse developer
content: A data warehouse developer creates and manages large databases called "data warehouses". These databases store lots of historical and current data from various sources. Businesses use this data with tools like BI (Business Intelligence) to make decisions. The job involves designing, building, and maintaining the database, using techniques like ETL (Extract, Transform, Load), and ensuring it's efficient for querying and analysis.

title: power bi
content: Power BI is an easy-to-use business intelligence (BI) tool that lets you analyze, visualize, and share your data insights in a simple and interactive way. It helps businesses connect to different data sources, work with the data, and create engaging reports and dashboards using a drag-and-drop interface. Its built-in AI features help find patterns and trends, making it easier for organizations to make smart decisions based on their data.

title: eda
content: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is an essential part of data analysis where you explore and comprehend your dataset using various statistical and graphical techniques to discover patterns, relationships, and trends within it. This process helps identify issues like missing values or outliers, and aids in determining which variables are most important for further study. EDA is the foundation of business intelligence that enables better decision-making by providing insights into your data's underlying structure.

title: lessons learned
content: In BI, "lessons learned" means understanding valuable information from past experiences, projects, or choices. This helps businesses find ways to improve, streamline processes, and make better future decisions. It comes from carefully examining completed activities, looking at what worked well, what didn't, and why, with the goal of improving overall performance and effectiveness.

title: user story
content: A user story is a brief, informal description of a feature or functionality from an end-user's point of view in software development. It explains what happens when a specific action is taken by the user, helping to clarify requirements and improve communication between stakeholders. In Business Intelligence (BI), user stories can be used to define and prioritize features that make BI tools and dashboards more usable and effective for users.

title: data source
content: A data source is a collection of raw facts that can be accessed, retrieved, and analyzed by various tools and applications. In the context of Business Intelligence (BI), it refers to where data comes from, like databases, spreadsheets, files, or even external sources such as web APIs or social media platforms. Data is extracted, transformed, and loaded into a BI system for further processing and reporting.

title: snowflake schema
content: A Snowflake Schema is a database design method where tables are arranged into separate, "snowflake-shaped" layers based on their connections. Each layer represents a specific level of detail, with the top layer having main fact tables and lower layers containing related dimension tables. This hierarchical structure helps in efficient querying and analysis by organizing data according to its natural business context.

title: control chart
content: A control chart is a visual tool used in business intelligence to track and analyze how well a process performs over time. It shows data points (like measurements or outcomes) along their respective time periods, with lines called "control limits" that show the acceptable range of variation within the process. By comparing new data points to these limits, analysts can quickly see if the process is stable, in control, or out of control, allowing them to make timely improvements.

title: funnel chart
content: A funnel chart is a graph that shows how many users or leads move through different stages of a process, like a narrowing funnel shape. It helps businesses see where they lose people and improve their sales or marketing plans.

title: data manager
content: A data manager is a professional who organizes, stores, and maintains large amounts of data within an organization. They ensure that data is collected, processed, and accessible to the right teams while keeping it secure and compliant with regulations. In Business Intelligence (BI), they play a vital role in preparing and managing data sources for analysis, enabling informed decision-making through accurate and timely insights.

title: jour fixe (regularly scheduled meeting)
content: A "jour fixe" is a regular meeting in the business world. It's a set time when team members or stakeholders consistently gather to discuss progress, share insights, and make decisions about projects or initiatives. This structured communication helps keep everyone informed, on track, and working efficiently within an organization.

title: business analyst
content: A business analyst is a professional who works with organizations to identify, analyze, and solve complex problems by examining their current processes, systems, and data. They collaborate closely with stakeholders to understand the organization's goals and objectives, then use their analytical skills to develop strategies that improve efficiency, reduce costs, and increase revenue. In the context of Business Intelligence (BI), a business analyst may also gather and interpret data from various sources, identify trends and patterns, and provide insights for strategic decision-making.

title: front-end
content: Front-end refers to the part of a digital product or app that users interact with directly. In Business Intelligence (BI), it means designing and creating interactive dashboards, charts, and interfaces for people to easily access, analyze, and understand data. This involves choosing suitable visuals, making sure it works well on different devices, and including easy-to-use navigation features.

title: 5-why method (5w)
content: The 5-Why Method (also known as 5W) is a problem-solving technique that involves asking "why" five times to find the main cause(s) of an issue. It helps you understand the real reasons behind a problem and makes better decisions by focusing on core issues, not just their symptoms. This method is especially useful in business intelligence for analyzing data trends and discovering hidden factors affecting performance or outcomes.

title: sql server analysis services (ssas)
content: SQL Server Analysis Services (SSAS) is a powerful tool in Microsoft's Business Intelligence suite that lets you create, deploy, and manage databases for analyzing large amounts of data. It helps with efficient querying, providing insights through multidimensional analysis and predictive modeling. SSAS transforms complex data into meaningful information, making it easy to access and analyze using various reporting tools, helping businesses make informed decisions.

title: conversion rate
content: A conversion rate measures how many users or visitors complete a specific action (like buying something or signing up) out of the total number in a certain time frame. It's important for businesses because it helps them see if their marketing and website are working well, so they can improve where needed to get better results.

title: bubble chart
content: A bubble chart is a graphical tool used in business intelligence that shows data points as circles or bubbles. The size of each bubble represents the value of a specific metric, while its color can indicate another attribute or category. This visualization method makes it easy to compare multiple variables within a dataset and is useful for various applications like financial analysis, market research, and project management.

title: data visualization
content: Data visualization is a way to show complex information using charts, graphs, maps, or other images that represent data points, trends, and relationships within the data. It helps people understand and analyze data more easily, allowing businesses to make informed decisions based on insights from their data in an easy-to-digest format.

title: box plot
content: A box plot is a clear graph that shows how numbers in a set are spread out. It includes the middle value (median), the values below and above it (quartiles), and any unusual very high or low numbers (outliers). The box goes from the lower to higher quartile, with a line inside for the median. Lines called "whiskers" extend from the ends of the box to the smallest and largest non-extreme values. Outliers are shown separately beyond the whiskers. Box plots help us see how numbers are grouped, find unusual numbers, and compare different sets of numbers.

title: analytics
content: Analytics is the process of studying raw data to find valuable insights and make informed decisions. In business intelligence, it involves gathering, organizing, and understanding data from various sources to discover patterns, trends, and connections that can help companies improve their operations, enhance customer experiences, and boost growth.

title: level
content: In Business Intelligence (BI), "level" means organizing data in a hierarchical way to make it more meaningful. It helps users analyze information at different levels of detail, like product sales with categories like country, region, city, store, and individual products, for better insights into performance across various dimensions.

title: line chart
content: A line chart is a simple graph that connects dots representing specific values at different times or categories. It's often used in business to show how things change over time or compare them across groups. The horizontal axis usually shows the independent factor (like time), and the vertical axis shows the dependent factor (like sales). Each line on the chart represents a separate set of data, making it easy to see trends and relationships between different variables.

title: surrogate key
content: A surrogate key is a unique code given to each record in a database, replacing the actual data that serves as the primary key. It's an artificial, non-meaningful value used to keep data connections correct and make searching through different tables easier. In business analysis, it simplifies working with data by providing a consistent reference point for all records.

title: agile
content: Agile is a flexible, adaptable way of managing projects that focuses on teamwork, change, and constant improvement. In the field of Business Intelligence (BI), an agile approach lets teams quickly adjust to new needs, prioritize tasks based on their importance, and provide useful insights in a timely manner by developing parts of the project step-by-step and getting feedback often.

title: analysis services
content: Analysis Services is a set of tools within Microsoft's BI platform that helps with data processing, storage, and querying for reporting and analysis purposes. It mainly focuses on multidimensional data modeling, data mining, and creating OLAP cubes to support decision-making in businesses.

title: project manager
content: A Business Intelligence (BI) project manager is a professional who oversees planning, executing, and completing projects involving data analysis and software development. They ensure tasks are done within budget, timeline, and scope while coordinating with various teams like analysts, developers, and stakeholders. Their responsibilities include setting goals, creating plans, allocating resources, tracking progress, and ensuring successful delivery of the BI solution.

title: roi (return on investment)
content: Return on Investment (ROI) is a percentage that shows how much profit an investment brings compared to its cost. It helps businesses see if their investments, like marketing campaigns or new equipment, are worth it. A positive ROI means the investment made money, while a negative one means it lost money.

title: cost-benefit analysis
content: Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) is a decision-making tool that compares the potential advantages and disadvantages of a specific business action or investment. It involves evaluating estimated costs against expected benefits to determine if the proposed course of action is financially viable and offers a favorable return on investment. This process helps businesses make informed decisions by considering both tangible factors (like money) and intangible factors (such as time, resources).

title: stacked bar/column chart
content: A stacked bar/column chart is a graphical tool used in business intelligence that shows multiple categories within each bar or column, allowing you to compare both individual parts and the whole. It does this by stacking the categories either vertically (for bars) or horizontally (for columns), showing how each category contributes to the total value. This visualization helps identify trends and patterns across different segments in a single chart.

title: index
content: In the field of business intelligence (BI), an index is a well-organized set of data elements that helps efficiently find and arrange information. It's like a tool that quickly locates specific records or data points within large datasets by assigning unique identifiers to each entry. These indices can be based on one or more attributes, such as product names, customer IDs, or dates, which speeds up query processing and enhances the performance of BI applications.

title: executive dashboard
content: An executive dashboard is a clear visual tool that shows top-level data like KPIs and other key metrics for senior leaders. It gives real-time, easy-to-read information about the most important parts of the business, helping decision-makers quickly monitor operations, spot trends, and make smart choices.

title: milestones
content: In business intelligence (BI), a milestone is a significant event within a project timeline that marks progress towards completing a specific goal or phase. These measurable achievements help track overall progress, allowing stakeholders to assess the project's status and make necessary adjustments.

title: mmp (minimal marketable product)
content: A Minimal Marketable Product (MMP) is the simplest version of a product or service that can be launched while still offering value to customers. In Business Intelligence, an MMP is a basic but functional solution that meets the essential needs of its target audience and serves as a base for future improvements. It focuses on delivering core features without unnecessary complexity, enabling businesses to gather feedback, validate assumptions, and make updates based on user requirements.

title: in memory
content: In Memory (IM) means processing data directly in a computer's main memory (RAM), instead of using traditional storage devices like hard drives or SSDs. This speeds up access, retrieval, and manipulation of data, making it ideal for Business Intelligence applications that require real-time analytics and quick query responses.

title: business driver
content: A business driver is an important factor or key measure that affects a company's strategic choices, targets, and overall success. It's something in the business you can measure that directly impacts its performance, growth, or profitability. In the world of Business Intelligence (BI), understanding and tracking these drivers helps companies make smart decisions based on data-driven insights.

title: operational reporting
content: Operational Reporting involves gathering, examining, and presenting important data from daily business activities in a clear format. It helps businesses track performance, spot patterns, and make smart choices by offering real-time insights into key operational measures. This type of reporting is crucial for organizations to streamline processes, enhance efficiency, and accomplish their strategic objectives.

title: dimension table
content: A dimension table is an important part of data warehousing and BI systems. It focuses on specific aspects or features of something, like time, products, customers, etc. Each row in a dimension table represents a unique level within that aspect, enabling multi-dimensional analysis and reporting.

title: sankey diagram
content: A Sankey diagram is a chart that shows how things move or are distributed among different categories or stages in a process. It uses nodes (areas) connected by arrows, with the width of each arrow showing how much is moving. This helps businesses see relationships between parts and use it for understanding resources, energy, and other important data.

title: candlestick chart
content: A candlestick chart is a graphical way to display financial market data for a specific time period, like one day. Each vertical line (candle) shows the opening, closing, high, and low prices during that time. The body of the candle represents the difference between the opening and closing prices, while the top and bottom wicks show the highest and lowest prices. This tool helps traders see market trends and make better decisions.

title: database
content: A database is an organized collection of electronic data in a computer system. It helps efficiently store, find, and manage information. For businesses, it's the base for understanding and sharing data to make decisions.

title: doughnut chart
content: A doughnut chart, also called a ring chart or annular chart, is a circular graph used in business intelligence that shows data by dividing a circle into sections, with each section representing a specific category or value. The center of the circle is empty, creating a "hole" or "doughnut-like" appearance, which helps visualize and compare data within each section more easily. This format is especially useful for comparing parts to the whole or highlighting the relative proportions of different categories in a dataset.

title: hierarchy
content: A hierarchy is a structured order where items are ranked based on importance, authority, or complexity. In Business Intelligence (BI), it helps organize and categorize data for efficient analysis and decision-making. Users can view data at different levels of detail by navigating through the hierarchical structure using drill-down or roll-up techniques.

title: lead and lag
content: In Business Intelligence (BI), "lead" and "lag" refer to shifting data points in a dataset based on time periods. A "lead" moves a data point forward by a certain number of periods, while a "lag" moves it backward by the same amount. These operations help analyze trends, predict future values, and compare performance over time.

title: collaborative business intelligence
content: Collaborative BI is a teamwork approach where people work together within teams or across organizations to analyze, interpret, and share insights from business data. It uses technology platforms that allow real-time sharing, visualization, and collaboration among stakeholders, helping them make informed decisions collectively.

title: data analysis expressions (dax)
content: Data Analysis Expressions (DAX) are powerful formulas used in Microsoft's Business Intelligence tools like Power BI and its predecessor, Power Pivot. DAX lets you do complex calculations and manipulate data within the platform, creating custom metrics, KPIs, and visualizations for business insights. It works with tabular data models and has a syntax similar to Excel's formula language, making it accessible for those familiar with spreadsheets.

title: drill through/drill down
content: Drill-through/Drill-down is a way to explore more detailed information in a Business Intelligence (BI) report or dashboard by clicking on specific parts, like categories, subcategories, or individual data points. It helps users understand the data better by going deeper into the details.

title: crm
content: CRM (Customer Relationship Management) is a collection of methods, actions, and technologies that businesses use to handle and enhance their connections with customers throughout the entire time they are a customer. It involves gathering, storing, and examining data about customers to improve service, sales, and marketing efforts. A typical CRM system includes tools for managing customer information, tracking interactions, and automating communication processes.

title: gantt chart
content: A Gantt chart is a simple visual tool for project management that shows tasks within a project, their start and end dates, and how they depend on each other. It helps plan, schedule, and track the progress of a project by clearly showing the timeline of activities, making it easy for stakeholders to understand the project's status and make informed decisions.

title: bi
content: In the context of Business Intelligence (BI), "bi" refers specifically to "Business Intelligence." It is a field that involves collecting, storing, and analyzing data from various sources within an organization to support strategic decision-making. Bi tools and techniques help businesses identify trends, patterns, and insights that can be used to improve performance, optimize resources, and drive growth.

title: radar chart
content: A radar chart, also called a spider or star graph, is a helpful tool in Business Intelligence that shows multiple factors (or dimensions) for individual data points. It displays each factor as an axis from the chart's center, with values plotted along these axes to create a multi-angled, circular diagram. This type of chart effectively shows how different factors contribute to one entity's overall performance or characteristics, making it useful for comparing and analyzing various aspects simultaneously.

title: sales dashboard
content: A sales dashboard is a clear visual display of important sales data, like revenue, new customers, and success rates. It uses special tools to show real-time information about the business's sales activities. This helps businesses make smart decisions by quickly spotting trends, patterns, and areas that need improvement in their sales performance.

title: pie chart
content: A pie chart is a circle divided into sections, each representing a different category in a dataset. The size of each slice shows the proportion or amount for that category, making it easy to compare them visually. Often used in business intelligence, it helps display categorical data clearly.

title: network diagram
content: A network diagram is a visual map that shows how different parts within a system or organization are connected. In the world of Business Intelligence (BI), it can show how data flows, how different systems communicate, and the relationships between databases, servers, and other important elements involved in collecting, processing, and analyzing information. It's a helpful tool for understanding and improving the structure and performance of a BI system.

title: smart objectives/goals
content: Smart objectives or goals are specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) targets set within an organization's strategic planning process. They help guide data analysis efforts towards meaningful insights that contribute directly to organizational success by providing clear direction, focus, and motivation for employees.

title: data management
content: Data management is about organizing, storing, protecting, and retrieving information within an organization throughout its lifecycle. This includes activities like collecting, integrating, validating, transforming, and archiving data to ensure it's accurate, consistent, and accessible when needed for decision-making in business intelligence applications.

title: bi project sponsor
content: A BI Project Sponsor is a crucial supporter who actively promotes and drives a Business Intelligence (BI) project within an organization. They provide funding, resources, and influence to ensure the successful completion of the project. The sponsor also helps align the project with organizational goals, facilitates communication between teams, and ensures that the project stays on track and delivers expected results.

title: in-memory analytics
content: In-memory analytics is a method that uses computer memory (RAM) to analyze and report on large datasets quickly, instead of traditional storage devices like hard drives. This speeds up querying, processing, and visualization by keeping data in high-speed RAM, which is faster than slower disk-based systems. By using this approach, businesses can efficiently gain insights from their data and make informed decisions in real time.

title: data warehousing
content: Data Warehousing is the process of gathering, storing, and organizing large amounts of structured and unstructured data from various sources into one central place called a "data warehouse". This data helps businesses with advanced analytics, reporting, and decision-making. A data warehouse usually follows either a star or snowflake schema to make it easy to query and analyze the stored information.

title: treemap
content: A treemap is a visual way to show hierarchical data using rectangles (tiles). Each tile represents a category or item in the dataset, with its size showing how much value or quantity it has. This helps you easily compare and analyze different categories' sizes in large datasets for trends, patterns, and outliers in Business Intelligence.

title: services delivery manager (bi delivery team)
content: A Services Delivery Manager in a Business Intelligence (BI) team is responsible for overseeing the entire process of delivering BI solutions to clients or internal stakeholders. They make sure projects are completed on time, within budget, and meet quality standards. Their role involves working with different teams like data analysts, developers, and project managers to ensure smooth execution and successful deployment of BI services.

title: olap cube
content: An OLAP cube is a powerful tool that organizes data along various dimensions (like time, location, or product categories) into a multidimensional structure. This allows users to analyze large datasets quickly and efficiently by providing pre-calculated aggregations and interactive slicing, dicing, and pivoting capabilities for better decision-making in business intelligence applications.

title: data cleansing
content: Data cleansing is the process of fixing incorrect, inconsistent, or missing information within a dataset. It involves removing or correcting errors, standardizing formats, and ensuring all data is useful for analysis. This improves the quality and reliability of the data, leading to more accurate insights and better decision-making in business intelligence applications.

title: full load
content: Full Load means putting all the data into a database or warehouse for analysis in Business Intelligence (BI) systems. It includes past, current, and new data being added at that time. This complete dataset is used to create insights and reports within BI applications.

title: stakeholder
content: In simple terms, a stakeholder in Business Intelligence (BI) is anyone who has an interest or gets affected by the results of data analysis within a company. This includes employees, customers, suppliers, shareholders, and even the local community. These stakeholders are important because their needs, expectations, and viewpoints should be taken into account when creating and implementing BI systems to ensure success and impact.

title: jet reports (previously jet professional)
content: Jet Reports is a strong business intelligence tool, formerly known as Jet Professional. It helps users create, customize, and automate financial and operational reports from Microsoft Dynamics ERP systems. By simplifying data extraction from these systems, it transforms the data into easy-to-understand visualizations or spreadsheets for better decision-making.

title: sql server integration services (ssis)
content: SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) is a robust tool within Microsoft's SQL Server platform that helps users integrate and transform data from various sources into desired destinations. It simplifies the process of managing and analyzing business intelligence data by allowing you to extract, transform, and load data easily. SSIS offers an intuitive interface for designing and executing complex data processing tasks, making it a vital part of modern data management strategies.

title: kimball approach
content: The Kimball Approach is a BI methodology that focuses on building data warehouses based on business needs and processes. It involves extracting, transforming, and loading (ETL) data from various sources into one central repository for analysis and reporting. This approach uses dimensional modeling to optimize the warehouse's performance and support decision-making by business users.

title: mdm
content: MDM stands for Master Data Management. It is the process of keeping important business information (like customers, products, or suppliers) accurate, complete, and consistent across an organization's various systems and applications. This helps ensure all departments rely on a single, trustworthy source of data, which improves decision-making and operational efficiency.

title: business user
content: A business user is a person within an organization who uses data, reports, or tools from Business Intelligence (BI) systems to make decisions. They are usually non-technical professionals who rely on insights and analyses provided by these systems for their roles in the company.

title: single version of the truth (svot)
content: A "Single Version of the Truth" (SVOT) is a consistent and accurate representation of data across all business processes and systems within an organization. It ensures everyone has access to the same, up-to-date information, eliminating discrepancies and promoting better decision-making. In Business Intelligence, achieving SVOT involves integrating various sources of data, standardizing data formats, and establishing clear data governance policies.

title: user story
content: A user story is a brief, informal description of a feature or functionality from an end-user's point of view in software development. It explains what happens when a specific action is taken by the user, helping to clarify requirements and improve communication between stakeholders. In Business Intelligence (BI), user stories can be used to define and prioritize features that make BI tools and dashboards more usable and effective for users.

title: use case
content: A use case is a clear, organized explanation of a specific interaction between someone or another system and an app or system in a work setting. It details the steps that an actor (a person or another system) follows to accomplish a certain goal within a software program. Use cases help define what a software solution should do and what it needs, making sure it works well for its users.

title: change management
content: Change management is about organizing how an organization adapts to new technologies, tools, or processes in a planned, step-by-step way.
