content: A column-level constraint is a rule that applies to individual columns in a table, limiting or defining the kind of data allowed in those columns. These rules help keep data accurate and consistent within a database. Examples include setting a specific data type (like integer or string), assigning a default value for new rows, or establishing connections with other tables using foreign keys.

title: data dictionary
content: A data dictionary is like a detailed guidebook for a database. It holds information about each table, field (column), their types, rules, and other details. This helps you understand how the database is structured and organized.

title: trigger
content: A trigger in SQL is an automated action that happens due to specific events within a database. It's like a rule that gets executed automatically when certain conditions are met, such as when data changes in a table (like inserting, updating, or deleting). Triggers help enforce business rules, keep data accurate, and automate repetitive tasks.

title: surrogate key
content: A surrogate key is a unique code given to each record in a database table, usually just one column with numbers or letters. It serves as a main identifier and doesn't have any special meaning related to the data it represents. Its purpose is to consistently reference and link records across different tables without relying on their actual content, which can change over time.

title: all operator
content: An "ALL" operator in SQL compares a given value with all others in a specified column or set of values. It returns TRUE if the specified value is greater than or equal to every other value, and FALSE otherwise. The ALL keyword ensures that each comparison is made independently without considering any other comparisons.

title: commit
content: A "commit" in the context of databases refers to saving the recent modifications you make, like inserting, updating, or deleting data, into the database permanently. In SQL, these changes aren't saved immediately but are temporarily stored in memory until you explicitly tell the system to commit them. Once committed, those changes become permanent and can be seen by other users or applications accessing the same database. If an error occurs before a commit, all the changes made during that session will be discarded (rolled back).

title: mongodb
content: MongoDB is a NoSQL database that uses flexible, JSON-like documents to store data. Unlike traditional SQL databases with fixed tables and columns, MongoDB offers dynamic and scalable storage through collections of documents with varying fields and values. It's designed for handling large volumes of unstructured or semi-structured data, making it popular for modern applications requiring flexible and efficient data management.

title: ash
content: Ash in a database refers to the leftover data after it has been processed or deleted. In SQL (Structured Query Language), this term isn't explicitly defined, but its effects on storage and management are significant. When you delete or update records, the original data becomes "ash" - still stored within the system, but no longer accessible through regular queries. This concept is crucial for understanding database optimization and data recovery techniques.

title: dml
content: DML stands for Data Manipulation Language. It includes SQL statements that let you insert, update, or delete data in your database tables without changing their structure. Common DML commands are INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE.

title: sqlite
content: SQLite is a lightweight, standalone database engine that stores data in a single file with .db or .sqlite extension. It uses the SQL language for querying and managing data, making it easy for developers familiar with SQL databases. Unlike other SQL databases, SQLite doesn't need a separate server process and can be directly embedded into applications, providing a simple and efficient way to store and retrieve data.

title: sqlcode
content: SQLCODE is a numeric value returned by an SQL engine after executing a statement or command. It represents the status of the operation, with each number corresponding to a specific error condition or success message. This helps developers and users understand if their SQL statements were executed successfully or encountered any issues during execution.

title: xe
content: XE (XML Extended) is a custom data type in Oracle Database that lets you store XML documents directly as native data types. It allows you to handle XML data using SQL and PL/SQL functions, making it more convenient to work with XML data within the database system.

title: non-equi-join
content: A non-equi-join is a type of join operation in SQL that combines rows from two or more tables based on an inequality comparison rather than an exact match between their columns. It lets you compare values using operators like "<", ">", "<=", ">=", and "<>". This allows you to perform operations such as finding all customers who have ordered more than 5 items, or identifying employees who earn less than the average salary.

title: asm
content: ASM (Automatic Segment Space Management) is a feature in Oracle Database that automatically handles storage space for database segments. It eliminates manual allocation and expansion of segment space, simplifying administration tasks. Instead of using methods like MANUAL or MANUAL_EXTEND, ASM lets the database automatically manage space within its storage units called disks.

title: view
content: A "view" in SQL is a virtual table created from existing tables in your database. It lets you make custom, read-only copies of data by choosing specific rows and columns based on certain conditions. Think of it as a saved search query that can be used like an actual table.

title: char
content: In SQL, a 'char' represents a fixed-length character data type. It stores a single character or a combination of characters within a specified length. This means that regardless of how many characters are stored, it always takes up the same amount of space in the database. For example, if you define a column as 'char(5)', it will store exactly 5 characters, even if only one is actually used.

title: second normal form (2nf)
content: Second Normal Form (2NF) is a rule for organizing data in relational databases that ensures each column in a table depends only on the primary key, not any other non-key columns. This helps avoid repeating information and keeps your database design consistent.

title: inner join
content: An inner join is a SQL operation that combines rows from two or more tables based on matching values in specific columns (called join keys). It returns only those records where there are matches between the joined columns, excluding any unmatched records. This results in a combined dataset with common data points across the selected tables.

title: couchbase
content: Couchbase is a flexible, distributed database that uses NoSQL technology to store data in documents, similar to JSON format. It combines the speed of key-value stores with the richness of structured data, making it efficient and scalable for managing various types of information. Unlike traditional SQL databases, it doesn't require predefined schemas and allows dynamic data modeling through its document-oriented approach.

title: otn
content: In SQL (Structured Query Language), "OTN" stands for Operator Number. It represents a specific type of data that refers to an operator or function in a database system. OTN is often used as a parameter in stored procedures, functions, or triggers to specify which operation should be performed on a set of data. This helps standardize and simplify the process of defining and using operators within SQL operations.

title: having clause
content: A "HAVING clause" is a part of an SQL query that filters the results of a GROUP BY operation, similar to the WHERE clause but applied after grouping data. It helps you analyze and summarize your data more effectively by only including groups that meet specific criteria in your final results.

title: oracle fusion
content: Oracle Fusion is a collection of integrated enterprise software apps that help businesses manage tasks like finance, HR, supply chain, and customer relations. It combines different Oracle products into one platform for a unified user experience. In an SQL glossary context, it's a complete software environment that supports SQL queries to access and manipulate data in its various applications.

title: ambiguous
content: Ambiguous (in SQL) means a situation where an SQL statement or expression has multiple possible interpretations due to unclear syntax, conflicting keywords, or insufficient information. This can cause unexpected results or errors when executed. To prevent ambiguity, always use clear and well-structured language in your SQL statements.

title: grant
content: In SQL, a grant is permission given to users or roles for specific actions within a database system. It allows them to read, write, or manage data. Grants help control and manage access to resources, ensuring only authorized individuals can execute certain tasks on the database.

title: user
content: In simple terms, a "user" in SQL (Structured Query Language) is someone or something that works with a database system to do tasks like getting, adding, changing, and removing data. They use special commands called SQL queries, which follow certain rules. This could be a person like a developer or analyst, or another program talking to the database.

title: denormalize
content: Denormalization means creating a database design with redundant data, meaning some information is stored in multiple places within the same or different tables. This goes against normalization, which aims to remove redundancy for better data consistency. In denormalization, the goal is to improve query performance by reducing the need for complex joins between related tables, but it may use more storage space and compromise data consistency.

title: privilege
content: In SQL, privilege means special permissions given to users or roles in a database system. These permissions allow them to do things like read, write, or manage data and objects within the database. By controlling these privileges, administrators can decide who gets access to what information and resources, keeping data safe and ensuring it's used properly.

title: alias
content: An alias in SQL is a shorter name you give to a table or column within a query for easier readability and reference. It temporarily renames the table or column during a statement, without changing its original name in the database. This helps avoid confusion when working with complex queries involving multiple tables or columns with long names.

title: cursor
content: A cursor is like a bookmark in a database. It saves the current row or group of rows being worked on during an SQL query. This helps you go through all the results one by one, making it easier to handle large amounts of data or do complex tasks on specific records. Imagine it as a pointer that moves along the rows returned from a query, allowing you to access and change data efficiently.

title: any keyword
content: An "ANY keyword" in SQL is used to compare values with multiple items from a list or subquery. It allows you to perform operations such as finding records where a value is greater than, less than, equal to, or not equal to any of the specified items. The ANY keyword can be applied to comparison operators like >, <, =, and !=. For example, in a WHERE clause, you might use "WHERE column_name IN (value1, value2, ...)" or "WHERE column_name NOT IN (value1, value2, ...)".

title: ocp
content: OCP (Optimistic Concurrency Protection) is a method in SQL to prevent conflicts when multiple users work with the same data at once. It tracks the latest version of each record and ensures changes are based on the most recent information, avoiding conflicting updates and maintaining data integrity and consistency.

title: rman
content: RMAN (Recovery Manager) is a robust tool for Oracle databases that helps administrators create consistent backups, perform point-in-time recoveries, and manage storage efficiently. Unlike traditional file-based backups, it operates at the database block level, offering more flexibility and control over the backup and restore process.

title: relation
content: In SQL, a relation is a two-dimensional table made up of rows (also called tuples or records) and columns (called attributes). Each row contains unique values for each attribute, and all the data in one column has the same type. Relations are the basic units of relational databases, allowing efficient storage and retrieval of organized information.

title: nchar
content: nchar is a fixed-length character data type in SQL, used for storing text data in specific languages or locales. It ensures the specified length of characters is always maintained, up to 4000 characters. This data type helps maintain consistency across different languages or locales when storing strings with consistent lengths, avoiding issues related to variable-length character strings.

title: anonymous block
content: An anonymous block is a self-contained section of SQL code that doesn't have a name or label. It's enclosed within delimiters (usually DECLARE or BEGIN...END) and can contain variable declarations, conditional statements, loops, and other SQL commands. Its purpose is to execute a series of related operations in one unit without needing a named procedure or function.

title: operator
content: An operator in SQL is a symbol or keyword that performs specific actions on values or expressions within a query. These operators include arithmetic (+, -, *, /), comparison (=, <>, <, >, <=, >=), and logical (AND, OR, NOT) operations. They help manipulate data and filter records in a database, enabling you to extract useful information from your data.

title: adf
content: An Autoregressive Distributed Lag (ADF) model is a statistical method used in time series analysis to test for stationarity, specifically whether a given time series follows a random walk or has a unit root. While ADF isn't directly applicable within SQL, it can help identify trends and seasonality in your dataset, which can determine if a series is stationary or non-stationary. In such cases, you may want to consider using other statistical methods like differencing or moving averages within the SQL environment to transform your data into a stationary form before further analysis.

title: postgresql
content: PostgreSQL is an open-source relational database system that follows SQL standards. It has strong features like full ACID compliance, advanced querying abilities, and extensive support for various data types and storage options. Its flexibility and scalability make it suitable for a wide range of applications, from small projects to large enterprise systems.

title: interval
content: An interval in SQL means a continuous range of values within a specific column. It helps group data into meaningful ranges, like age groups or salary brackets. This makes it easier to analyze and aggregate the data.

title: dynamic sql
content: Dynamic SQL means creating and running SQL statements during a program's runtime instead of defining them beforehand in a fixed script or code. This provides more flexibility and adaptability when dealing with changing data, like user inputs or shifting database conditions. In dynamic SQL, you build and execute the SQL statement using programming language code, which allows for variables, conditional logic, and other programming features to create custom queries on-the-fly.

title: on delete cascade
content: On Delete Cascade is a rule in databases that, when you delete a main record (like an employee), it also deletes the connected smaller records (like their orders) automatically. This helps keep data organized and prevents extra, unused records (called orphans).

title: directory
content: In simpler terms, a directory in SQL is like a folder that organizes related tables or files within a database system. It helps keep things tidy and easy to find when you need them. While directories aren't directly mentioned in SQL commands, we can think of them as a way to group and arrange our database objects (like tables) for better organization and maintenance.

title: session
content: A SQL session is a temporary connection between a user's application and a database server, during which the user can perform multiple transactions within one continuous interaction. Each session has a unique identifier (session ID) assigned by the server to track and manage interactions.

title: outer join
content: An outer join in SQL is a type of join operation that combines all rows from one or both tables, even if they don't have matching records in the other(s). It includes results from an inner join (where there are matches) and adds extra rows when there are no matches. This helps you compare data across different tables while still including all relevant information from each table.

title: pls_integer
content: "pls_integer" is a type in Oracle's PL/SQL language for variables that store whole numbers (integers). It only allows integer values, preventing non-integer data. This helps keep data accurate and simplifies error handling when working with numbers

title: unique key/unique constraint
content: A unique key (or unique constraint) in SQL ensures each value in a specific column or combination of columns within a table is different from all other values in the same column(s). It helps maintain data integrity by preventing duplicate entries, so every record has a unique identifier.

title: synonym
content: A synonym is a word or phrase that has the same meaning as another in a specific context. In SQL (Structured Query Language), it lets you give alternative names to columns within a table, so users can refer to the same data using different terms. This improves readability and maintains database schemas better.

title: dcl
content: Data Control Language (DCL) in SQL are commands that handle access rights and privileges for database objects like tables, views, or procedures. They help maintain data security by controlling who can perform specific operations within the database. DCL statements include GRANT, which assigns permissions, and REVOKE, which removes them.

title: b-tree (or b-tree index)
content: A B-Tree is a tree-like data structure used in databases, like SQL systems, to efficiently store and retrieve sorted data. It allows for faster search operations by reducing the number of disk I/O operations needed. Each node can contain multiple keys and child nodes, making it useful for organizing and accessing large amounts of data quickly, which is essential for database indexing.

title: binary integer
content: A binary integer is a number using only 0s and 1s in a base-2 system. In SQL, it's a data type for storing such values, often used in bitwise operations or boolean conditions.

title: pragma
content: A pragma in SQL is a directive that guides or impacts how the SQL engine operates during compilation or execution. It doesn't directly change data stored in the database but rather influences how SQL processes queries and statements. Pragmas are usually used to give hints or suggestions to the SQL engine, enabling it to optimize its performance based on specific needs or conditions.

title: extent
content: An "extent" refers to the storage space assigned for a table in a database. It's a physical part of data storage that holds the actual rows of the table. Each extent can consist of multiple pages, and each page can store several rows. In SQL, understanding extents helps manage disk space usage and improve performance by controlling how data is stored and accessed within tables.

title: google firestore
content: Google Firestore is a flexible, scalable database service from Google Cloud Platform (GCP). It lets developers store and sync data in real-time across devices, with easy data modeling and querying options. Unlike traditional SQL databases, it uses a document-based model where data is organized into collections of documents, each containing key-value pairs or nested subdocuments. This makes it easier for apps to scale and adapt to changing needs.

title: fetch
content: Fetch is a process in SQL (Structured Query Language) that retrieves or obtains specific rows or columns of data from a database based on your desired criteria, such as filtering by certain values or ordering the results. It doesn't directly return the result set; instead, it works with other commands like SELECT to fetch and display the desired data.

title: cardinality
content: Cardinality refers to the number of results returned by a query in a database system like SQL. It also describes relationships between tables, such as one-to-one, one-to-many, or many-to-many. In simple terms, it's about counting data instances in a table or connections between rows in different tables.

title: apache hbase
content: Apache HBase is a powerful, scalable NoSQL database built on top of Hadoop's file system (HDFS). It efficiently stores and retrieves vast amounts of sparse data, similar to how SQL databases handle structured data. Unlike traditional relational databases like MySQL or PostgreSQL, it organizes data into tables with rows and columns using a column-family structure, making it ideal for handling large datasets that don't fit well in traditional SQL databases.

title: index-organized table
content: An index-organized table (IOT) is a special type of table in SQL databases where each column is automatically indexed based on its position within the table. This means that instead of having separate indexes for each column, like in traditional tables, an IOT organizes data in a way that allows for faster retrieval and sorting operations. It's particularly useful when you frequently query data in a specific order or need to retrieve specific ranges of data.

title: metadata
content: Metadata is information about other data or sets of data. In SQL (Structured Query Language), it means extra details stored with a database table, like column names, types, and rules. This helps users understand the structure and content without looking at the actual data.

title: clause
content: A clause in SQL is a piece of a sentence that has one or more words and conveys a complete idea. It usually includes a subject and a verb (predicate) and can be either independent (a standalone statement) or dependent (part of a larger statement). Clauses help organize sentences, making them clearer to read and comprehend.

title: raw
content: Raw data is the original, unprocessed information collected before it's organized, analyzed, or transformed into useful insights using SQL commands. It can come from various sources like databases, spreadsheets, or files and may have inconsistencies, errors, or missing values that need to be fixed during processing.

title: table-level constraint
content: A table-level constraint is a rule set at the database table level to limit or verify data within that specific table. These rules help maintain data consistency by ensuring only valid and consistent data is stored in the table. Examples of such constraints are NOT NULL, UNIQUE, CHECK, and FOREIGN KEY constraints.

title: data mart
content: A data mart is a targeted database designed for specific business needs within an organization. It has a smaller set of data from the main company warehouse, tailored to the particular requirements and analysis of a department. Data marts are often built using SQL databases and can be updated regularly with new information, helping users make informed decisions based on relevant, up-to-date data.

title: function
content: A function in SQL is a reusable piece of code that does a specific task or operation. It has input values (arguments) and gives an output based on its built-in rules. Functions can make complex calculations easier, make your code more readable, and keep things consistent across different database actions.

title: sequence
content: A sequence in SQL refers to a continuous set of values produced by a built-in function called "sequence generator" or simply "sequence". It automatically increases each new value by a specified step, usually starting from 1. Sequences are commonly used as primary keys or for generating unique identifiers in tables. They ensure that every newly inserted row is assigned a distinct and incremented value without the need to manually specify it.

title: sga
content:
SGA, or System Global Area, is a shared memory space in an Oracle Database Server that stores important data structures and background processes to enhance performance. It keeps frequently accessed data in memory, reducing disk I/O operations. The main components of SGA are:

1. Shared Pool: Stores SQL statements, parse trees, and shared library code.
2. Redo Log Buffer: Temporary storage for redo log entries before they're written to the online redo logs.
3. Database Buffer Cache: Stores blocks of data read from disk into memory for faster access.
4. Large Pool: Used by Oracle's background processes and other non-memory-managed components.
5. Java Pool: Memory space allocated for running Java code within the database server.

title: self join
content: A self join is an SQL technique where a table joins with itself to get data involving multiple instances of the same record within the same table. It lets you compare or combine rows from the same table based on a common field, creating temporary relationships between records. This can be helpful for tasks like finding all pairs of employees who share the same manager, or identifying all orders placed by a customer for a specific product.

title: full outer join
content: A Full Outer Join (also called a full join) combines rows from two or more tables by including all records from both sides when there are matching values in the joined columns. If no match is found, it includes NULL values for the missing fields. This operation ensures that every row from each table is included in the final result set, either with a corresponding match or as a standalone record.

title: bounce
content: A "bounce" in the context of databases refers to when a query or transaction fails to execute properly due to reasons like syntax errors, missing tables/columns, or insufficient permissions. In SQL, a bounce is an unsuccessful attempt to perform an operation on a database, and it's important to identify and fix these issues for smooth data processing.

title: literal
content: A literal in SQL is a fixed value directly included in your query. It can be a number, string, or date and isn't based on any column values from the database. Literals provide the actual data you want to work with in your query, not just referencing stored data in a table.

title: lock
content: A lock is a tool in SQL that temporarily blocks access to certain data or resources for multiple users simultaneously, ensuring data consistency and integrity. It lets only one person at a time change a specific record while others can still read it. This prevents conflicts and ensures the accuracy of transactions.

title: nullif
content: Nullif is an SQL function that compares two expressions and returns NULL when they are equal. It's useful for comparing values without returning a result if they are the same. The syntax is: `NULLIF(expression1, expression2)`.

title: primary key
content: A primary key is a special code given to each item in a table of a database. It makes sure that no two items have the same code, which helps find things quickly and keeps data accurate. In SQL, you can mark a column as a primary key using the PRIMARY KEY rule.

title: rowid
content: A rowid is a unique code given to each entry (or "row") in a table within a database system. It helps find specific rows quickly when doing tasks like updates or deletions, especially in SQLite and similar SQL-based systems.

title: wildcard
content: A wildcard in SQL is a special symbol that can stand for one or more unknown values in a search query. It helps you find information even when the exact value isn't known, making it easier to retrieve relevant data from a database. The most common wildcards are the percent sign (%) which represents zero, one, or multiple unknown characters, and the underscore (_) which stands for exactly one unknown character.

title: oca
content: OCA (Object-Column Alias) is a SQL feature that lets you give a different name or "alias" to a column in your query results. This can help simplify complex queries, make them easier to read, and allow you to reference specific columns more easily in later operations. The new alias doesn't change the actual data, but just provides an alternative way of referring to that particular column.

title: nvarchar2
content: NVARCHAR2 is a type in Oracle SQL that stores variable-length text data using Unicode encoding. It can hold up to 32,767 bytes and supports multiple languages with different character sets. Unlike VARCHAR2, which uses the database's national character set, NVARCHAR2 uses the Unicode character set, making it better at handling characters from various languages.

title: timestamp
content: In SQL, a timestamp is a type of data that shows a specific moment in time, usually stored as a mix of date and time parts (like year, month, day, hour, minute, second). It helps you know when an event happened or was recorded inside your database.

title: adr
content: An ADR (Application Data Record) in SQL is a single row or record within a table that holds data related to an application. It represents a specific instance of data stored in a database, which can be accessed, modified, or removed using SQL commands. Each ADR has unique values for its columns and serves as an individual entry in the table.

title: uml
content: UML (Unified Modeling Language) is a standard visual language for designing and representing software systems. It uses diagrams and symbols to show a system's structure, behavior, and how its parts interact. While not directly related to SQL, understanding UML can help in designing and communicating the structure and relationships within a database schema.

title: number
content: In SQL, a number is a value that represents a quantity or position within a dataset. It can be an integer (whole number) or a decimal (fractional number). Numbers are used for various purposes like filtering data, performing calculations, and ordering records. They play a vital role in working with databases and manipulating data using SQL commands.

title: foreign key
content: A foreign key is a field or set of fields in one table that links (points to) another table's primary key. It helps create connections between tables in a database, ensuring data consistency and accuracy. For example, if you have a 'Customers' table with a 'customer_id' as its main identifier, and an 'Orders' table with a 'customer_id' referencing the 'Customers' table, it allows you to link each order to a specific customer.

title: nls
content: NLS stands for National Language Support and refers to a SQL feature that allows handling multiple languages within a database system. It enables storing, manipulating, and retrieving data in various languages, as well as displaying results in the user's preferred language. This is especially useful for global businesses or multilingual environments where users interact with the database using different languages.

title: joins
content: Joins in SQL (Structured Query Language) combine rows from two or more tables based on a shared column called a "join key" or "join condition". They help retrieve and analyze data across multiple tables by creating a unified dataset. There are various types of joins, such as INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL OUTER JOIN, each with its specific use case.

title: sparse representation
content: Sparse Representation means representing data or signals using only a few non-zero parts while keeping most of the original information. In machine learning, it helps with tasks like reducing dimensions and selecting important features. It's especially useful for high-dimensional data where many details might be unnecessary. By focusing on significant components, sparse representation can improve efficiency and accuracy in various applications such as image compression, speech recognition, and anomaly detection.

title: matrix factorization
content: Matrix Factorization is a machine learning technique that breaks down a large, complex matrix into smaller, simpler matrices or vectors. It's commonly used for recommendation systems, where we predict missing values based on observed data. The process involves splitting the original matrix into two smaller ones, which can be multiplied to reconstruct the original one. This factorization helps reveal hidden patterns and relationships in the data, making predictions or recommendations easier.

title: width
content: In machine learning, "width" means the number of features (or dimensions) in a dataset or a model's input. It shows how many factors are considered when making predictions or decisions. More width can lead to more complex models but may also increase the risk of overfitting.

title: reporting bias
content: Reporting bias is a consistent difference in how certain events or outcomes are reported due to factors like memory, personal beliefs, or external influences. In Machine Learning, it can lead to skewed data and impact the accuracy and reliability of predictive models if not handled properly during data collection and preprocessing stages.

title: role prompting
content: Role prompting is about giving clear instructions to a machine learning model during training. These instructions guide the model to learn and perform specific tasks like image classification, language translation, or sentiment analysis. This way, the trained model can effectively fulfill its intended purpose within a given context.

title: classification
content: Classification in machine learning is about teaching a model to sort data into separate groups or categories based on their features. It involves training an algorithm with labeled data (data already categorized) and then using it to predict the most likely category for new, unseen data. The aim is to create a rule-based system that can accurately classify future instances without needing human help.

title: transfer learning
content: Transfer learning means using an already trained machine learning model as a starting point for a new task, instead of training a new one from scratch. It saves time and data by leveraging the knowledge gained during initial training, especially when dealing with limited datasets or similar problem domains.

title: supervised machine learning
content: Supervised learning is when we teach algorithms using labeled examples, where both the input (features) and output (labels or targets) are given. The algorithm learns from this data to make accurate predictions for new, unseen inputs. It's like teaching a student with example problems and their correct answers, so they can solve similar future problems on their own.

title: static inference
content: Static inference is about estimating a variable's value based on its fixed context within a machine learning model. It involves analyzing how input features relate to an output target, with the data staying constant and not changing over time. Unlike dynamic inference, which considers how things change over time, static inference only looks at the current state of the data for predictions or decisions.

title: probability distribution
content: A probability distribution is a way to describe the chances of different outcomes in random events or processes. It assigns numbers (probabilities) to each outcome, with all probabilities adding up to 1. In machine learning, we use these distributions to represent uncertainties and make predictions based on data.

title: rater
content: A rater, in machine learning, is a person or system that judges how good or important certain data points (like texts, images, or predictions) are. They help make machine learning models better by giving feedback on the model's performance, which can then be used to improve its decision-making process.

title: multinomial regression
content: Multinomial Regression is a method in machine learning that predicts multiple categorical outcomes, not just two like binary logistic regression. It does this by assigning a specific probability to each outcome and estimates all probabilities at once. The input is then classified into one category based on the highest predicted probability.

title: parameter update
content: A parameter update means changing or tweaking the values of variables in a machine learning model while it's being trained. These variables are learned from data by repeatedly using an optimization method like gradient descent, which calculates the direction and size of changes based on how far off predicted results are compared to actual targets. The aim is to minimize errors or loss, resulting in a more accurate model.

title: saver
content: A "saver" in machine learning is a tool that saves important data like intermediate results, model parameters, and other useful info during the training process. This helps with efficient storage and retrieval, so you can resume training or use pre-trained models for further improvements.

title: ranking
content: Ranking is the process of organizing things in a list based on their importance or relevance according to certain criteria. In machine learning, ranking algorithms help predict which items are preferred by sorting search results or recommending products. These algorithms analyze data and assign scores, then rank them accordingly.

title: oblique condition
content: An oblique condition in machine learning refers to a situation where an output (dependent variable) depends not just on one or more inputs (independent variables), but also on how these inputs interact with other variables. This means the effect of an input on the output can change depending on the values of other inputs, creating a complex and non-linear relationship between them. In simpler terms, it's when the influence of a feature on the outcome isn't constant across all levels of another feature.

title: reward
content: In simple terms, a reward in Machine Learning is a number given to an algorithm after it makes a decision or takes an action. This number helps the learning process change its future decisions and get better over time. In reinforcement learning, rewards can be positive (for good outcomes) or negative (for bad outcomes), helping the agent learn what actions are best in its environment.

title: cross-entropy
content: Cross-entropy is a loss function in machine learning for classification problems. It compares predicted probabilities from a model to actual class labels, showing how much information is lost when predicting one probability distribution using another. Lower cross-entropy values mean better alignment between the model's predictions and true class labels.

title: r-squared
content: R-squared, also called "coefficient of determination," is a statistic that shows how much the independent variables in a regression model explain the changes in the dependent variable. It ranges from 0 to 1, with higher values meaning better fit and predictive power. In simpler terms, it helps you understand how well your machine learning model can explain the observed data.

title: sparse feature
content: A sparse feature is a data attribute in machine learning that has many missing or zero values. It's called "sparse" because it contains lots of empty spaces, meaning there are fewer non-zero entries compared to the total possible entries. Sparse features can be efficiently managed by specialized algorithms and data structures, which store only the non-zero values along with their corresponding indices, thus saving memory and improving computation speed.

title: nonlinear
content: Nonlinear means patterns or connections in data that don't follow a straight line when shown on a graph. In machine learning, nonlinear models can handle complex relationships between input features and output targets, unlike simple linear models which assume a straightforward, straight-line connection. These more advanced models are especially helpful for dealing with complicated datasets where a basic linear model might not work well.

title: parameter server (ps)
content: A Parameter Server (PS) is a distributed computing system used in machine learning, especially for training deep neural networks. It efficiently manages communication between many worker nodes and a central server called the Parameter Server. This server stores and updates shared model parameters during training. The design allows faster convergence and scalability by distributing computations across multiple machines while maintaining a single source of truth for the model's parameters.

title: sequence model
content: A sequence model is an algorithm that learns from ordered sets of data called sequences. It analyzes and makes predictions or generates outputs by examining each element in the order they appear, considering their context. These models are useful for tasks like natural language processing, speech recognition, and music generation.

title: model capacity
content: Model capacity refers to a machine learning model's complexity, which is based on its ability to learn and represent various patterns in the data. It involves factors like the number of parameters (weights) it has, the complexity of its architecture, and how much non-linearity it can capture. A more complex model can potentially fit more intricate relationships between input features and output targets, but may also risk overfitting to noise or outliers in the data.

title: one-shot prompting
content: One-shot prompting is a machine learning technique that trains or fine-tunes a model using just one example (or a few examples) of the target task, instead of needing a large dataset. This method enables the model to generalize from limited data and quickly adapt to new tasks by utilizing its existing knowledge. It's especially helpful in zero-shot and few-shot learning situations where gathering big datasets is difficult or costly.

title: deep learning
content: Deep learning is a type of advanced machine learning that uses multi-layered artificial neural networks to find complex patterns in large datasets. It can automatically learn how to represent data in a hierarchical way, allowing it to make accurate predictions and recognize patterns without needing manual feature selection. Unlike traditional methods, deep learning algorithms discover the most important features from raw input data through multiple layers of interconnected nodes.

title: linear regression
content: Linear Regression is a basic machine learning method that finds a straight-line connection between two or more variables using observed data. It predicts a continuous outcome (dependent variable) based on one or more input features (independent variables). The model assumes a simple, straight-line relationship and aims to find the best fitting line that minimizes the gap between predicted values and actual observations.

title: stochastic gradient descent (sgd)
content: Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) is an optimization method used in machine learning to find the best settings for a model by continuously adjusting these settings based on a small, randomly chosen sample of data points. It works by calculating the gradient (rate of change) of the loss function with respect to the parameters using this subset, and then updating the parameters accordingly. This process is repeated until an optimal solution is found or a certain number of iterations are reached. SGD is particularly useful in large datasets because it can efficiently find good solutions due to its random sampling nature.

title: lstm
content: LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) is a type of neural network designed for handling sequence data. It remembers important information for longer periods by using "cell states" and "gate mechanisms". Unlike traditional RNNs, it can learn long-term dependencies in data without the issue of vanishing gradients. LSTMs are commonly used in natural language processing, speech recognition, and time series forecasting tasks.

title: upweighting
content: Upweighting means increasing the importance or influence of specific data points in a Machine Learning model's decision-making process. This is done by assigning higher weights to certain features, instances, or classes during training, which makes them more impactful on the final model. By upweighting, you can highlight the significance of these aspects and potentially improve the model's performance when handling similar data in the future.

title: out-group homogeneity bias
content: Out-group homogeneity bias is when machine learning models treat people from different groups (out-groups) as more similar than they actually are. This can result in incorrect predictions or unfair treatment for individuals in those out-groups, because the model doesn't recognize their unique traits and variations within the group.

title: feature selection
content: Feature selection is about choosing the most important input variables from your dataset that have the biggest impact on predicting the target variable in a machine learning model. By removing unnecessary or duplicate features, it helps improve the accuracy and efficiency of the model while preventing overfitting. This step is crucial before training a machine learning algorithm as part of data preprocessing.

title: pipeline
content: A pipeline in Machine Learning is a sequence of steps that turn raw data into useful insights or predictions. It's an organized way to combine different algorithms, preprocessing techniques, and evaluation metrics to efficiently handle data and create accurate models. Each step can be customized and improved separately, making the analysis process flexible and scalable.

title: model parallelism
content: Model Parallelism is a method of dividing a large machine learning model into smaller parts called "chunks". These chunks are then trained simultaneously across different hardware devices, like processors or GPUs. This technique helps use computational resources more efficiently and speeds up training time by distributing the workload among multiple devices. By splitting the model in this way, it's possible to train larger and more complex models that would be too computationally demanding for a single device.

title: one-vs.-all
content: One-vs-All (OvA) is a method in machine learning for handling multi-class classification tasks. It involves training a separate model for each class, predicting if an instance belongs to that specific class or not, considering all other classes as alternatives. This approach simplifies the problem by transforming it into multiple binary classification problems.

title: parameter-efficient tuning
content: Parameter-efficient tuning involves optimizing a smaller set of shared parameters that affect multiple tasks or models, rather than individually adjusting each task or model's unique parameters. This approach enables more efficient and effective fine-tuning across various tasks or models by leveraging the knowledge learned from one task or model to improve others. It is particularly useful in situations with limited data or computational resources, as it reduces the overall number of trainable parameters, leading to faster training times and lower memory requirements.

title: test
content: A test in machine learning means checking how well a trained model works with a different set of data. This helps us see if it can make good predictions or decisions using new, unseen information. It's important for making sure the chosen method is effective and adjusting its settings properly.

title: quantile
content: A quantile is a value within a dataset that divides it into equal parts, such as two for a median or four for quartiles. In machine learning, they help understand and describe data distribution, especially in outlier detection and scaling techniques like Quantile Transformation.

title: rectified linear unit (relu)
content: A Rectified Linecular Unit (ReLU) is a basic yet powerful activation function often used in neural networks for Machine Learning. It simply outputs the input value if it's positive, and zero otherwise. This helps avoid the vanishing gradient issue, enabling deeper networks to learn more complex patterns. In essence, ReLU simplifies learning by only passing on positive values through the network layers.

title: split
content: In machine learning, splitting means dividing a dataset into smaller groups called "training sets" and "test sets". This process helps evaluate an algorithm's performance by training it on one group (training set) and testing its accuracy on another group (test set). The aim is to ensure the model performs well with new, unseen data.

title: loss function
content: In machine learning, a loss function is a mathematical equation that compares predicted values from a model with actual observed values. It measures how well the model performs by assigning a numerical value to the difference between predictions and truths. The aim is to minimize this loss during training, so predictions get closer to true values.

title: underfitting
content: Underfitting means a machine learning model is too basic to grasp the main patterns or connections in the data properly. This leads it to not learn from the data well and make poor predictions or decisions. In simpler words, an underfitted model doesn't generalize well from its training data to new, unseen data, resulting in low accuracy on both the training and test datasets.

title: roc curve
content: An ROC curve is a graph that shows how well a binary classification model works at different threshold settings. It compares True Positive Rate (how many positive cases it correctly identifies) to False Positive Rate (how many incorrectly identified as positive). A larger area under the curve means better overall performance.

title: xla (accelerated linear algebra)
content: XLA, or Accelerated Linear Algebra, is a tool created by Google that enhances and speeds up mathematical calculations in machine learning software. It converts high-level commands into efficient lower-level instructions, allowing faster execution across various devices like CPUs, GPUs, and TPUs (Tensor Processing Units). By using XLA, developers can boost their machine learning models' performance without needing to write low-level code themselves.

title: variable importances
content: Variable Importance refers to how much each input feature (variable) affects predicting the output in a Machine Learning model. It helps find which variables are more important for accurate predictions and can guide choosing and improving features. The importance is usually calculated using measures like Gini Impurity, Information Gain, or Mean Decreased Impurity, depending on the algorithm used.

title: normalization
content: Normalization is a method in machine learning that adjusts input data so each feature has an average (mean) value of zero and a spread (standard deviation) of one. This ensures all inputs are treated equally, regardless of their original scale or range, which can enhance algorithm performance and accuracy by preventing larger features from overwhelming smaller ones.

title: scoring
content: Scoring in machine learning means measuring and rating a predictive model's performance by comparing its predictions to actual results. It assigns a numerical score to each prediction, helping us see how well the model works on new, unseen data. This evaluation helps find ways to improve the model's accuracy.

title: feature engineering
content: Feature engineering is the process of creating or transforming existing variables in a dataset to improve machine learning model performance. This involves finding useful patterns, relationships, or features within the data that better represent the problem and help the model make accurate predictions. It often requires domain knowledge, statistical techniques, and creativity to generate meaningful new variables that capture important aspects of the data.

title: prompt engineering
content: Prompt Engineering is about creating and refining input questions for language models like chatbots or text generators to make their answers more accurate, relevant, and coherent. It involves understanding what these models can do, designing clear prompts, and adjusting them based on the desired outcome.

title: rotational invariance
content: Rotational invariance means an algorithm or model stays the same when its input data is rotated. This means the output doesn't depend on how the input is oriented. It's crucial for tasks like image processing and computer vision, as it allows models to identify objects regardless of their positioning within an image.

title: predictive ml
content: Predictive Machine Learning (ML) is a method that uses past patterns from data to forecast future outcomes or make predictions about unknown data. It involves teaching models with input data, then using those trained models to generate accurate predictions for new, unseen data. This helps businesses and organizations make informed decisions by providing insights into future trends and behaviors.

title: sampling bias
content: Sampling bias is an issue in statistics where a sample chosen for analysis doesn't accurately represent the overall population. In machine learning, this can happen when training data isn't reflective of the entire dataset or real-world situations. This may result in poor performance on new data or incorrect predictions. To prevent sampling bias, it's essential to ensure that selected samples are diverse and representative enough to truly capture the population's distribution.

title: wisdom of the crowd
content: Wisdom of the Crowd means that a group's combined intelligence often performs better than individual experts or even an expert's predictions. In machine learning, this concept is used in algorithms that gather and combine information from many sources (crowds) to make more accurate predictions or decisions than any single source could provide alone. This idea assumes that various individuals, when given a chance to share their knowledge, can achieve better outcomes collectively.

title: machine learning
content: Machine learning is a part of artificial intelligence where algorithms learn from data without being explicitly programmed. It allows computers to improve their performance on tasks by finding patterns in the input data and adjusting themselves accordingly. This process often uses large amounts of data and can be applied to various fields like image recognition, natural language processing, and predictive analytics.

title: spatial pooling
content: Spatial pooling is a method in neural networks that combines or chooses the most important parts from a specific area (or "pool") within an image or other spatial data. It helps reduce complexity and find key details, making it easier for the network to spot patterns and make predictions. This technique is often used in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for tasks like image recognition.

title: metric
content: A metric is a numerical measure that evaluates how well a machine learning model performs or its quality. It compares the model's predictions with actual outcomes to determine performance. Metrics are divided into two main types: loss functions, which help minimize errors during training, and evaluation metrics, which assess the final model's performance on new, unseen data. Common evaluation metrics include accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.

title: kendall's
content: Kendall's Tau is a non-parametric way to measure how closely two sets of ranked data match each other, like scores given by two judges in a competition. It ranges from -1 (perfectly opposite order) to 0 (no correlation) to 1 (perfectly same order). Unlike Pearson's correlation, it doesn't assume any specific distribution for the underlying data.

title: synthetic feature
content: A synthetic feature is an artificial attribute made from combining, changing, or manipulating existing data features. It helps improve model performance, make it easier to understand, or simplify the data for machine learning algorithms. This can involve basic math like adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, or more complex functions such as polynomial expansion or interaction terms.

title: momentum
content: Momentum is a method used during training neural networks in machine learning that speeds up convergence by introducing "inertia" or momentum into gradient descent. It keeps the direction and pace of model updates based on past iterations, preventing the algorithm from getting stuck in local optima. This is done by adding a portion of the previous update to the current one, which smooths out fluctuations and enables more efficient learning.

title: negative class
content: In machine learning, a "negative class" refers to the data that doesn't belong to the target or positive class. It helps train classification models by teaching them what isn't part of the desired category, which improves their ability to accurately identify and classify instances in the target class.

title: minority class
content: In simple terms, a "minority class" in machine learning is the less common category within a set of data with multiple categories. When solving classification problems, data is divided into distinct groups or classes. The minority class has fewer instances compared to other classes (majority classes). Balancing and addressing biases related to minority classes can be important for improving model performance and fairness in machine learning applications.

title: z-score normalization
content: Z-score normalization, or "z-scoring," is a method to make numerical data more comparable by transforming each value into a z-score. This score shows how many standard deviations an element is from the mean. By doing this, all variables are brought onto the same scale and become easier for machine learning algorithms to work with. To calculate a z-score, subtract the dataset's mean from each value, then divide by its standard deviation. The result is a new set of values that follow a standard normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1, making them easier to interpret and analyze in machine learning tasks.

title: missing values
content: Missing values are data points in a dataset that don't have corresponding information because of errors during collection or incomplete records. In machine learning, these gaps can cause problems when training models, as the algorithm might struggle to make accurate predictions without complete data. To address this issue, techniques like imputation (replacing missing values with estimated values) or deleting rows containing missing values are often used.

title: variance
content: Variance is a way to measure how much spread or variation there is in a set of numbers compared to their average value. It shows the average difference between each number and the overall average, squared. In machine learning, understanding variance helps find patterns, make predictions, and improve model performance by showing how different the data points are from the mean.

title: relu
content: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) is a common activation function in neural networks for Machine Learning. It adds non-linearity by outputting the input if it's positive, or 0 if it's negative: f(x) = max(0, x). This helps prevent the vanishing gradient problem and makes learning more efficient.

title: tpu resource
content: A TPU (Tensor Processing Unit) is a type of hardware designed by Google specifically for speeding up machine learning tasks. It consists of specialized processors, memory, and connections that work together efficiently to perform complex calculations on large datasets. This makes it faster than traditional CPUs or GPUs when training machine learning models.

title: serving
content: In simple terms, "serving in machine learning" means using trained models in real-world situations. It involves making predictions or decisions based on what the model has learned from data. This is important because it helps us apply the insights gained from training a model to solve practical problems.

title: masked language model
content: A masked language model is a type of neural network that predicts missing words in a text sequence. It learns from the surrounding words to create coherent sentences, keeping the original meaning intact.

title: n-gram
content: An n-gram is a continuous set of n items from a given text or speech stream, where n is a positive integer. In the context of Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning, it's often used to represent words or characters in a text corpus for tasks like language modeling, sentiment analysis, and text classification. For example, a 2-gram would be a pair of consecutive words, while a 3-gram would be a triplet of consecutive words.

title: baseline
content: A "baseline" in machine learning is a basic, simple model used as a comparison point for evaluating other methods. It represents the simplest possible approach to solving a problem, assuming no prior knowledge about the data or task. By comparing other models' performance against this baseline, we can measure their effectiveness and improvements made.

title: splitter
content: In simple terms, a splitter in machine learning is an approach or method that divides a large dataset into smaller, more manageable parts called "splits" or "folds". These splits are used for tasks like training and testing machine learning models. One part of the data helps train the model, while another part checks its performance. This process prevents the model from overfitting and ensures it can perform well with new, unseen data.

title: task
content: In simple terms, a task in machine learning is a problem that a model aims to solve using data patterns. It involves finding patterns within data sets and making predictions or decisions based on those patterns. For instance, an example of a task could be image classification, where the goal is for the model to categorize images into different groups (like cats vs dogs). Tasks can range in complexity and may include tasks like regression, clustering, or natural language processing.

title: descriptive statistics
content: Descriptive statistics are easy-to-understand numbers that show important features of a dataset, like average, middle value, most common value, spread, and shape. They include measures such as mean, median, mode, range, standard deviation, and quartiles. These help us understand the main patterns in our data before using them with machine learning algorithms.

title: online inference
content: Online inference means making predictions or decisions quickly using machine learning models as new data comes in continuously. Unlike batch processing where all the data is used at once, online inference allows for updates with incoming data streams and immediate responses. This approach is especially helpful in applications that need fast response times, like recommendation systems, fraud detection, and real-time analytics.

title: partial derivative
content: A partial derivative is a way in calculus to find how much a function's output changes when one input varies, but keeps all other inputs constant. In machine learning, it helps us understand the rate of change of a multivariable function with respect to just one variable, while keeping others fixed. This is especially useful for complex models like neural networks.

title: neural architecture search (nas)
content: Neural Architecture Search (NAS) is an automated process that discovers the best neural network designs for specific tasks, like image classification or language translation. It involves designing, evaluating, and refining candidate models using search algorithms, often guided by machine learning techniques such as reinforcement learning or evolutionary algorithms. The aim is to find the optimal architecture with minimal human intervention, resulting in high performance.

title: trigram
content: A trigram is a set of three consecutive words or characters in a text. In machine learning, it's commonly used as a feature for natural language processing tasks, like predicting the next word in a sentence or categorizing documents based on their content. For example, in the phrase "the quick brown fox," the trigrams would be ("the", "quick", "brown"), ("quick", "brown", "fox") and so forth.

title: tf.keras
content: tf.keras is a user-friendly tool built on TensorFlow for creating deep learning models in Python. It simplifies the process by providing pre-built layers, optimizers, and loss functions, so developers can focus on designing their models without worrying about low-level operations.

title: text span
content: A text span is a continuous part of a larger text. In the fields of Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning, it's often used in tasks like extractive summarization or named entity recognition. It refers to a connected series of words that can be taken from a document for further study or processing.

title: positional encoding
content: Positional Encoding is a method used in machine learning models, especially for Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Transformers, to give information about the relative or absolute positions of input data elements. It helps the model understand the time-based relationships between different inputs, allowing it to make more accurate predictions or generate meaningful outputs. This is done by adding a learnable vector to each input element, where the vector's components are designed to be sensitive to the input's position within the sequence.

title: precision and recall
content:
Precision and Recall are vital evaluation measures in machine learning classification tasks. They help assess the performance of a model by considering both true positives (correctly predicted positive instances) and false positives (incorrectly predicted positive instances). 

Precision measures how many correctly predicted positive instances there are among all instances that the model predicts as positive, indicating the reliability of the model in identifying actual positive cases. A high precision means fewer false positives.

Recall, on the other hand, measures the proportion of correctly predicted positive instances among all actual positive instances in the dataset. It indicates how well the model can find or detect all true positive cases. A high recall ensures that most true positives are found.

In summary, precision and recall are complementary metrics: a high precision ensures few false positives, while a high recall ensures most true positives are found.

title: stochastic gradient descent
content: Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) is an algorithm used in machine learning to find the best settings for a model by continuously adjusting these settings based on a small, randomly chosen part of the training data. It does this by computing the gradient (a measure of how much each setting should be changed) using that subset and then updating the settings accordingly. This process is repeated until it reaches an optimal solution or a certain number of iterations are completed. SGD is particularly helpful for large datasets, as it can reduce memory requirements and computational cost compared to other optimization methods.

title: markov property
content: A Markov Property means that a system's future state depends only on its current state, not its past states. In simpler words, the next event or outcome is determined solely by the present state and has no relation with any previous events or outcomes. This concept is often used in machine learning algorithms like Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) to model sequential data.

title: unlabeled example
content: An unlabeled example is a piece of data in a set that doesn't have a specific category or target assigned to it. In machine learning, datasets usually contain features (input variables) and labels (output variables), with the goal of finding patterns from labeled examples to make accurate predictions on new, unknown data. Semi-supervised learning uses both labeled and unlabeled instances: only a small portion has labels, while most don't. These unlabeled instances can still help improve model performance by revealing underlying structure and patterns within the data.

title: nlu
content: Natural Language Understanding (NLU) is a machine capability to grasp, interpret, and extract meaning from human language in forms such as speech or text. It combines techniques from natural language processing (NLP), machine learning, and artificial intelligence to enable computers to understand, analyze, and generate human language. NLU supports tasks like sentiment analysis, intent recognition, entity recognition, and more, which are essential for applications like chatbots, virtual assistants, and translation systems.

title: distributions
content: Distributions are models that show the chances of different outcomes in a dataset. In machine learning, they represent how data is structured, like the range of values within a feature or the connections between multiple features. They help us understand patterns and relationships between variables, which is important for tasks like prediction, classification, and clustering. Common distributions used in ML are Gaussian (normal) distribution, Bernoulli distribution, and multinomial distribution.

title: scikit-learn
content: Scikit-learn is a popular open-source Python library that makes machine learning easier by providing many algorithms and tools for data analysis and modeling. It simplifies tasks like classification, regression, clustering, and dimensionality reduction with easy-to-use APIs and efficient implementations. This tool is widely used in both research and industry because it's simple to use and reliable.

title: unsupervised machine learning
content: Unsupervised learning involves techniques where algorithms analyze data without specific instructions or labeled results. Instead, they discover patterns and relationships within the data on their own, such as grouping similar points (clustering) or finding underlying structures (dimensionality reduction). This approach is helpful when you have a large amount of unlabeled data and want to explore its structure and hidden patterns.

title: weighted alternating least squares (wals)
content: Weighted Alternating Least Squares (WALS) is a technique used in recommendation systems to predict missing values in a matrix. It alternates between updating rows and columns, considering their importance or weight. The goal is to minimize the least squares error between predicted and actual values, which helps improve predictions for unknown entries.

title: retrieval-augmented generation
content: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a method in language processing that combines text generation with data search. It creates new texts by including useful information from existing sources like databases or the internet. The process usually involves two main steps: first, it finds relevant data based on a specific question; second, it uses this data to enhance and generate new, coherent, and informative texts. RAG can be used in various applications such as chatbots, summarization systems, and content creation tools.

title: pjit
content: PJIT (Parallel Just-In-Time) is a method in machine learning that improves computation efficiency by dividing tasks into smaller, parallelizable parts. It does this by compiling and running code during runtime, similar to JIT Compilation (JIT). The "parallel" part means these smaller tasks can be run simultaneously on multiple processing units, which speeds up overall computation time. This is especially helpful in machine learning applications that require significant computational resources for handling large datasets.

title: tpu slice
content: A TPU slice is a part of Google's custom-designed hardware for machine learning tasks called Tensor Processing Units (TPUs). It divides the power of a full TPU into smaller, more manageable sections that can be assigned to different tasks or users. This way, multiple slices can work together on larger problems, effectively scaling up computation without needing additional physical TPUs.

title: nonstationarity
content: Nonstationarity is when a time series' statistical properties (like mean, variance, or correlation) change over time. This means that a model trained on one part of the data might not accurately predict future observations if the underlying patterns have shifted. In machine learning, dealing with non-stationary data often requires adaptive models or retraining the model periodically to account for these changes.

title: chatgpt
content: ChatGPT is a top-notch language model made by OpenAI that uses machine learning to create human-like text responses. It belongs to natural language processing (NLP) and is a type of transformer-based model, trained on lots of data to understand and respond to various inputs in a coherent way.

title: tensor
content: A tensor is a versatile collection of numbers arranged in multiple dimensions that helps represent complex connections between variables in machine learning models. It simplifies calculations by organizing data into structured formats, allowing for efficient mathematical operations across different dimensions. Tensors are widely used in deep learning algorithms to handle and analyze large datasets.

title: positive class
content: In machine learning, a "positive class" refers to the desired or target outcome in classification problems. It is the set of instances that your model should recognize and predict accurately. For example, if you're building a spam filter, 'spam emails' would be the positive class.

title: validation
content: Validation means checking a machine learning model's performance using a separate set of data not involved in its training. This helps ensure the model's accuracy and ability to generalize, by testing how well it can predict or classify new, unseen instances. It is crucial for creating dependable models and preventing them from overfitting to their training data.

title: test loss
content: Test loss is the difference between a machine learning model's predictions and the actual values during evaluation. It shows how well the model performs on new data, estimating its ability to generalize. Lower test loss means better model performance.

title: tensor size
content: A tensor size in machine learning refers to the dimensions or shape of a tensor, which is a multidimensional array containing numerical data like input features for a model or intermediate computations during processing. The size is determined by its number of dimensions and the length of each dimension, similar to the height, width, and depth of a data structure. For instance, a 2D tensor represents a matrix with rows and columns, while a 3D tensor signifies a cube-like structure with height, width, and depth.

title: objective function
content: An objective function in machine learning is a formula that measures a model's performance or quality. It helps optimization algorithms improve the model by either minimizing or maximizing it, depending on the specific problem. Essentially, it tells us how well our model is doing and guides it towards better predictions or decisions.

title: measures of association
content: Measures of Association are tools that show the connection between two variables in a dataset. They help us see how much one variable affects another, giving insights into their relationship or correlation. In machine learning, they play a big role in understanding and improving model performance by finding patterns and dependencies within data.

title: tpu master
content: A TPU Master is the main organizer in a Tensor Processing Unit (TPU) setup that oversees and plans tasks across several TPUs within a system. It manages resources, communicates between TPUs, and ensures efficient use of hardware for machine learning tasks.

title: predictive rate parity
content: Predictive Rate Parity is a concept in machine learning that ensures predictions made by a model stay consistent across different situations or contexts, without being affected by factors like time, location, or irrelevant variables. It aims to ensure accurate and fair forecasts regardless of the circumstances encountered.

title: translational invariance
content: Translational invariance means that a machine learning model's predictions stay the same even if the input data is slightly shifted or moved along one or more dimensions. In simpler words, it means that if you slightly move an image or any other type of data, the model should still recognize and classify it correctly. This concept is especially important in tasks like computer vision where small shifts in images can happen due to camera movement or other factors.

title: value imputation
content: Value imputation is a method in data preprocessing for machine learning that fills missing or unknown values in a dataset with estimated ones. This helps keep the dataset complete and useful by avoiding loss of information due to missing values, allowing better training of models on complete data. Common ways to do this include using the mean/median, mode, or regression-based methods.

title: online
content: Online learning is a process where an algorithm updates its model parameters in real-time as new data arrives. This differs from batch learning, which processes all data at once before updating the model. In online learning, each new piece of data is processed individually and immediately incorporated into the model's understanding, allowing it to adapt continuously and learn incrementally.

title: pandas
content: Pandas is a powerful Python library for handling and analyzing data. It offers easy-to-use tools like tables and spreadsheets to work with structured datasets. With its strong features, pandas helps clean, transform, and visualize data efficiently, making it vital in Machine Learning tasks.

title: ml
content: Machine Learning (ML) is a field where we create algorithms and models for computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed. It uses techniques like supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and reinforcement learning, allowing machines to find patterns, recognize features, and improve their performance over time.

title: tabular q-learning
content: Tabular Q-Learning is a learning method in reinforcement learning where an agent learns the best actions in a given environment by updating a table of action values (Q-table). The agent interacts with the environment, takes actions, and receives rewards or penalties. As it gains experience, it improves its Q-table to assign higher values to better actions, eventually finding the optimal policy for making decisions in that specific environment.

title: mini-batch
content: A mini-batch is a smaller group of data samples chosen from the entire dataset to train a machine learning model during each iteration in an optimization algorithm, like gradient descent.
