It helps make training more efficient and less memory-intensive by using these smaller batches instead of the full dataset. The size of the mini-batch usually balances computational efficiency with model accuracy.

title: state-action value function
content: A "state-action value function" is a key idea in Reinforcement Learning (RL). It helps an agent guess how much reward it will get, on average, by taking a certain action from a specific situation or state. In simpler words, think of it like a guide that helps an agent choose what to do in different situations by predicting the results of those actions. This function is very important for learning the best way to act in RL systems.

title: stride
content: Stride means the distance between steps when going through a sequence in tasks like convolution in Machine Learning. In simpler words, it's how many positions you move ahead after processing each item in your data set. If stride is 2, you process every other element.

title: multi-class logistic regression
content: Multi-class Logistic Regression is a machine learning technique used to predict multiple categories from a set of inputs. It builds upon binary logistic regression by using several logistic functions, each representing a distinct category, to estimate the probabilities of different outcomes. The aim is to find the best weights for these functions that effectively separate the data into their respective classes.

title: feature extraction
content: Feature extraction is a process that turns raw input data into a simpler, more meaningful form for training machine learning models. It involves choosing or creating important features from the original data set, which helps reduce complexity and improve model performance. This often includes math operations like averaging, normalizing, or using statistical methods to find useful patterns in the data.

title: training
content: Training in machine learning means changing a model's settings based on examples called "training data". The goal is to learn a rule that can predict results for new situations, making the model better over time. This involves tweaking the model's internal parts using clever math methods and repeating with the training data until it works well enough.

title: sequence-to-sequence task
content: A Seq2Seq task is a machine learning problem where you take an input sequence and turn it into another output sequence. It has two main parts: the encoder processes the input, and the decoder creates the output using that information. These tasks are often used for language processing, like translating languages or generating text responses from prompts.

title: correlation
content: Correlation is a way to measure how two things are connected or depend on each other using numbers. It goes from -1 (meaning they go opposite ways) to 1 (meaning they go the same way), with 0 meaning no connection. In machine learning, finding these connections helps choose important parts for predictive models.

title: termination condition
content: A "termination condition" in machine learning is a rule that decides when an algorithm's training should end. It prevents overfitting by stopping the model from continuously learning from data, which could harm its ability to perform well on new, unseen data. Common termination conditions are reaching a maximum number of iterations, observing minimal improvement in loss or error function, or achieving desired accuracy or performance.

title: natural language processing (nlp)
content: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a part of AI that helps machines understand, interpret, and generate human language. It uses methods from linguistics, statistics, and machine learning to analyze, process, and make sense of natural language data. NLP applications include sentiment analysis, text classification, speech recognition, and language translation.

title: bias
content: Bias means mistakes in a machine learning model that cause it to make wrong predictions or decisions. It happens when the training data doesn't reflect real-world populations, making the model favor certain outcomes over others. This can be due to unbalanced datasets, incorrect assumptions, or biases within the data itself. To create accurate and fair models, reducing bias is essential.

title: perceptron
content: A perceptron is a basic type of artificial neural network, often used as a foundation for more complex models. It has input nodes, a central decision-making node called the "perceptron" or "neuron," and output nodes. The perceptron receives multiple inputs, multiplies them by their weights, sums these products, applies a step function (either threshold or sigmoid), and generates an output. It's mainly used for binary classification tasks, where it learns to separate data into two distinct classes based on the input features.

title: measures of central tendency
content: Measures of Central Tendency are methods to find the typical or average value in a set of data. They include the Mean (average), Median (middle number when sorted), and Mode (most common number). These measures help us understand the main trend in a dataset, which is useful for tasks like evaluating machine learning models and creating visualizations.

title: re-ranking
content: Re-ranking is the process of rearranging a list of items according to new information or criteria. In machine learning, it often involves using another model or algorithm to refine initial rankings produced by another model, which can enhance overall quality and relevance, especially with large datasets or complex ranking tasks.

title: perplexity
content: Perplexity is a measurement used in language processing and machine learning to assess how well a language model performs. It calculates how accurately a model predicts a set of sentences by averaging their probabilities. A lower perplexity score means the model works better, as it's more likely to generate the observed data.

title: savedmodel
content: A saved machine learning model is a file or directory that holds all the important parts (like weights, structure, and settings) needed to define a trained model. It lets you save, share, and reuse your trained models without needing the original training data or code. This means others can use your model in their projects, or you can keep using it across different situations or tasks.

title: tpu device
content: A TPU (Tensor Processing Unit) is a specialized hardware created by Google to quickly handle machine learning tasks. It's an ASIC (Application-Specific Integrated Circuit) specifically designed to perform complex matrix operations, which are essential in AI algorithms like neural networks. By taking over these calculations from traditional CPUs or GPUs, TPUs can significantly speed up the training and prediction of models, making them more efficient for large-scale AI applications.

title: subsampling
content: In machine learning, subsampling means choosing a smaller, representative sample from a large dataset for analysis or training. This helps avoid overfitting and improves model performance by simplifying the data used in training. It can be done through methods like random subsampling (also known as bootstrapping) or stratified subsampling, depending on the specific needs of a particular problem.

title: minimax loss
content: Minimax Loss is a strategy in machine learning that aims to minimize the maximum possible loss from all outcomes. It involves finding the best decision by considering the worst-case scenario among potential results, ensuring robustness and stability in models, especially for high-stakes predictions or uncertainties.

title: cross-validation
content: Cross-validation is a method in machine learning that checks how well a model works by splitting the data into several smaller groups. It trains the model using different combinations of these groups and tests it on the remaining group. This helps prevent overfitting, as the model learns from various parts of the data, and gives an honest estimate of its ability to generalize to new, unseen data.

title: regularization rate
content: The "regularization rate" is a key parameter in machine learning models that influences how much complexity we allow our model to have during training. It helps prevent overfitting by penalizing complex models. A lower regularization rate means less penalty, so the model can learn more complex patterns but risks overfitting. On the other hand, a higher regularization rate imposes stricter penalties, encouraging simpler models that might not capture all data patterns perfectly, but they generalize better and are less likely to overfit.

title: scale level
content: Scale Level refers to the level of detail in data analysis. In Machine Learning, it represents the level at which data is processed. A lower scale level involves working with individual data points (like pixel values in an image), while a higher scale level might involve analyzing patterns or features across multiple data points (such as identifying objects within an image). Essentially, it's about how much detail is being considered when examining the data.

title: multi-head self-attention
content: Multi-Head Self-Attention is a technique in neural networks that lets a model focus on different parts or connections within input data at once. It does this by dividing the input into several "heads" and separately applying self-attention to each head, then combining their results. This allows the model to detect various patterns and relationships across the input data, making it better at understanding complex dependencies and contexts.

title: replay buffer
content: A replay buffer is a storage system in reinforcement learning that saves past experiences (states, actions, rewards, and next states) during training. It helps the learning algorithm by randomly selecting mini-batches of these saved experiences to learn from. This prevents focusing too much on recent events and allows the agent to generalize better across different situations.

title: output layer
content: In simple terms, an "output layer" is the final part of a neural network model in machine learning. It generates predictions based on input data and what it has learned from earlier layers. The number of output layer neurons depends on the task: for classification tasks, it's equal to the number of classes; for regression tasks, there's just one neuron.

title: node (decision tree)
content: A node in a decision tree is where we decide or test something to split the data into smaller groups based on one feature's value. It helps build the tree, making it easier to classify and organize our input data for better understanding and prediction.

title: neuron
content: A neuron is a basic unit in artificial neural networks, modeled after real neurons in our brains. It receives information from other neurons or external sources, processes it, and then sends output to other neurons or the network's final result. In machine learning, neurons learn patterns and relationships within data, allowing the network to make predictions or decisions based on that knowledge.

title: tensorboard
content: TensorBoard is a helpful tool made by Google that lets you see and understand your machine learning projects better. It has interactive charts and graphs to show how your model learns, like loss curves and accuracy plots. By using it, you can find out how well your model is doing and make smart choices for improving it.

title: selection bias
content: Selection bias means that results in a study can be misleading because the people or information chosen for the analysis are not representative of the whole group they're supposed to represent. In machine learning, this happens when the training data doesn't match the target population, leading to poor performance on new, unseen data. This issue occurs when collecting and selecting data is influenced by factors related to what you're trying to predict, resulting in an imbalanced or skewed representation of different groups within the dataset.

title: spearman's
content: Spearman's Rank Correlation Coefficient is a non-parametric way to measure how strongly two variables are related without assuming they follow a straight line pattern. It works best with ordinal data, and it tells us if one variable consistently increases or decreases as the other does, even if the relationship isn't perfectly linear.

title: temperature
content: Temperature is the measure of how much energy particles in a substance or system have on average. In Machine Learning, it can be used as an input for predictive models, especially when forecasting time-series data where temperature changes can greatly affect things like weather and energy use. It's usually shown as a continuous number, often in Celsius or Fahrenheit scales.

title: one-shot learning
content: One-shot learning is a machine learning method where a model can learn from just one or a few examples of something to recognize and generalize new instances of that concept. It aims to reduce the need for lots of labeled data, making it more efficient in situations with limited training samples.

title: unsupervised learning
content: Unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning where algorithms analyze data without being told what to look for or given labeled results. Instead, they find patterns and relationships within the data on their own, trying to make sense of the input data. This is usually done through techniques like clustering and dimensionality reduction, which help organize and simplify complex datasets.

title: model training
content: Model training is the process of improving a machine learning algorithm by providing it with data. This helps the algorithm learn from patterns in the data and become better at making accurate predictions or decisions. It involves choosing an appropriate model, adjusting its settings, and assessing how well it performs on its task. The aim is to create a strong model that can effectively handle new, unseen data.

title: reinforcement learning from human feedback (rlhf)
content: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) is a method in AI where agents learn optimal behaviors by directly receiving feedback from humans. This process improves the agent's performance over time, making it more adaptable and user-friendly. The agent communicates with a human through natural language or other means, learning from their input to refine its actions and decisions.

title: oversampling
content: Oversampling is a method in machine learning where we increase the number of examples from minority classes in an unbalanced dataset by copying them. This helps balance class distribution, which can improve classification algorithms that struggle with imbalanced datasets. However, oversampling alone may not always solve the problem; it should be combined with other techniques like undersampling or ensemble methods for better results.

title: unidirectional
content: Unidirectional, in machine learning, means a model or process where information flows only one way, usually from input features to output predictions. This is different from bidirectional models that allow for two-way flow between inputs and outputs. In unidirectional models, dependencies are strictly earlier to later elements, making them simpler to train and understand but potentially limiting their ability to capture complex relationships in data.

title: k-nearest neighbors (k-nn)
content: K-Nearest Neighbors (K-NN) is a basic yet effective Machine Learning method that sorts new data points based on their similarity to existing labeled data points. It works by assigning a new point to the class most common among its 'k' closest neighbors in the training dataset, where 'k' is a user-defined number. The closer a neighbor is, the more it impacts the classification of the new point.

title: rank (tensor)
content: A tensor's rank is the number of dimensions it has. In machine learning, tensors are multidimensional arrays used for computations. For example, a 1D tensor is a vector (like [1, 2, 3]), a 2D tensor is a matrix (such as [[1, 2], [3, 4]]), and a 3D tensor is like a cube of numbers (e.g., [[[1, 2], [3, 4]], [[5, 6], [7, 8]]]). The rank determines the shape and complexity in machine learning operations.

title: wide model
content: A "wide model" in machine learning is a type of predictive model that combines manual feature engineering and automated feature selection techniques. It involves creating multiple interactions between input features and the target variable, effectively increasing the dimensionality of the input space. This allows the model to capture complex relationships between variables while still being interpretable. Wide models are often used in recommendation systems or other applications where understanding the impact of individual features on the output is important.

title: test set
content: A test set is a group of sample data used to assess a machine learning model's performance after it has been trained on a separate training set. It helps determine how well the model generalizes to new, unseen data and estimates its real-world accuracy. The test set should ideally resemble the actual data the model will face in practice, but it must not overlap with the training set to prevent overfitting.

title: similarity measure
content: A similarity measure is a method in machine learning that compares two things or data points based on their features to see how alike they are. It gives a number called the similarity score, which goes from 0 (completely different) to 1 (exactly the same). This score helps find connections between data points and can be used for tasks like grouping, categorizing, and making recommendations.

title: pre-training
content: Pre-training is the process of first teaching a machine learning model with lots of data to learn general patterns and representations. Then, it's fine-tuned on a smaller, specific task dataset. This helps use fewer training examples for the final task. It's often used in natural language processing and computer vision tasks, where pre-trained models like BERT or ResNet can be good starting points for more specialized applications.

title: word embedding
content: Word embedding means turning words into dense vectors (numbers) in a small space, where each word's vector shows its meaning and how it relates to other words. This helps machines understand similarities between words for tasks like sentiment analysis or text classification better.

title: auc (area under the curve)
content: AUC, or Area Under the Curve, is a way to measure how well a classification model works in machine learning. It shows the total area under the ROC curve, which compares true positive rates and false positive rates at different thresholds. The AUC value goes from 0 to 1, with higher values meaning better performance for the model.

title: permutation
content: A permutation in machine learning is reordering all possible combinations of elements from a set. It's important for algorithms like cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning, where we test different combinations to find the best solution. Permutations help us explore various data arrangements to enhance model performance or gain insights.

title: pmap
content: Pmap, short for "Parallelized Map," is a method in parallel computing that applies a function to multiple data elements at once. In machine learning, it speeds up calculations by dividing tasks among available CPU cores or even different machines. It works by splitting input data into smaller parts and processing each part separately on distinct threads or processes. The results are then combined for the final output, reducing computation time, especially with large datasets.

title: wasserstein loss
content: Wasserstein Loss, also called Earth Mover's Distance (EMD) or Optimal Transport Loss, is a tool in machine learning for assessing and improving similarity between two probability distributions. It calculates the "cost" of transforming one distribution into another by considering the least effort needed to move mass from one distribution to another. This loss function is especially helpful in tasks like domain adaptation or generative modeling, where the goal is to learn a mapping that aligns two distinct distributions.

title: hyperparameter tuning
content: Hyperparameter tuning is the process of optimizing certain values that control a learning algorithm itself, not the data it learns from. These hyperparameters are set before training starts and can greatly affect a model's performance. By adjusting these settings and evaluating their impact on the model's performance, you can enhance its accuracy and efficiency. This process is crucial for building strong and effective machine learning models.

title: predictive parity
content: Predictive Parity is about making sure a prediction model works equally well for everyone, no matter their gender or race. It helps avoid bias and unfairness in predictions by ensuring the model performs consistently across different demographic groups. In simple words, a fair predictive model should treat all individuals the same, regardless of which group they belong to.

title: tensor processing unit (tpu)
content: A Tensor Processing Unit (TPU) is specialized hardware designed by Google specifically to speed up machine learning tasks, especially those involving tensor operations. It's an ASIC (Application-Specific Integrated Circuit) that excels at performing mathematical computations on large arrays of numbers called tensors, which are fundamental in machine learning algorithms. By using a TPU, you can significantly speed up the training and inference processes for models like neural networks.

title: proxy labels
content: Proxy labels are stand-ins for actual target variables in machine learning tasks. They're used when getting the true target is hard or costly, but there's an easier-to-measure related variable that can serve as a substitute. By training models on these proxy labels, we can still learn useful patterns and make predictions about the original target variable.

title: recommendation system
content: A recommendation system is a tool that uses machine learning to predict and suggest items or actions for users based on their past behavior or preferences. It analyzes data like purchase history, search queries, or ratings to find patterns and make personalized suggestions. Its goal is to improve the user experience by providing relevant content or products, increasing engagement and satisfaction.

title: shape (tensor)
content: A "shape" in machine learning refers to the dimensions or size of a tensor. It is a multi-dimensional array that holds data points, where each dimension represents an attribute or feature. The shape is described as a list of integers, showing the number of elements along each dimension. For instance, a 2D tensor might have a shape (3, 4), meaning it has three rows and four columns.

title: tpu chip
content: A TPU (Tensor Processing Unit) chip is specialized hardware designed specifically to speed up machine learning tasks by efficiently executing mathematical operations like matrix multiplications and convolutions. By offloading these computations from general-purpose CPUs or GPUs, TPUs can significantly improve the training and inference of machine learning models, making them more accessible for a wide range of applications.

title: mesh
content: A mesh in machine learning is a way to organize and connect different data points or features. It helps with tasks like interpolation (filling gaps) or prediction. Each point has connections to its closest neighbors, creating a network-like structure. This makes it easier and faster to analyze complex patterns within the data.

title: unidirectional language model
content: An unidirectional language model is a type of algorithm that reads input text in one direction (usually left to right) and predicts the next word or phrase based on the previous words only, without considering future context. It can be simpler and faster than bidirectional models but may sometimes be less accurate.

title: temporal data
content: Temporal data is information that has timestamps or relates to time sequences. It includes various data points collected at different times, which can be used in machine learning to analyze patterns, trends, and changes over time. Examples are stock prices, weather data, and social media posts with timestamped dates.

title: threshold (for decision trees)
content: A "threshold" in Decision Trees is a specific value that separates instances (data points) into two distinct categories during decision-making. In binary classification problems, a threshold helps split the data based on a chosen feature, creating two homogeneous subsets of data. For example, when predicting if an email is spam or not, a threshold might be set at 0.5 for a certain feature like 'number of exclamation marks'. If the number of exclamation marks in an email exceeds this threshold, it would be classified as spam.

title: shrinkage
content: Shrinkage is a method in machine learning that simplifies models by reducing their coefficients towards zero, helping to prevent overfitting. Overfitting happens when a model learns the noise in the training data instead of the underlying pattern. By shrinking the coefficients, the model becomes more robust and performs better on unseen data. Examples of shrinkage methods are Ridge Regression (L2 regularization) and Lasso Regression (L1 regularization).

title: scaling
content: Scaling in machine learning is adjusting or transforming input data so that all features contribute equally to a model's performance. This is crucial when working with datasets containing variables measured on different scales, as it prevents some features from overshadowing others and ensures fair comparisons between them. Common scaling techniques are normalization (rescaling values to have an average of 0 and a standard deviation of 1) and standardization (subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation).

title: model selection
content: Model selection is about choosing the most suitable predictive model from various options for a specific dataset and problem. This involves assessing different algorithms, adjusting their parameters, and picking the one that performs best according to a chosen evaluation metric. It's crucial in machine learning as it helps ensure the selected model can effectively identify patterns in data and make accurate predictions.

title: transformer
content: A transformer is a special type of neural network designed for natural language processing tasks. It uses self-attention mechanisms to focus on different parts of input sequences when making predictions, rather than just considering each element independently or in a fixed order. This makes transformers highly effective at understanding and generating human language, as seen in models like BERT and GPT-3.

title: nan trap
content: A "nan trap" is a problem in machine learning where small numerical errors can cause bigger issues, often resulting in unexpected or wrong results. This term comes from the concept of "numpy nan" in Python, which represents missing or undefined values. In machine learning algorithms, these undefined values can spread and build up, leading to unstable models or incorrect predictions. To prevent this issue, it's important to properly handle and clean such data before training a model.

title: pax
content: Pax refers to the number of individual cases or samples in a dataset. In machine learning, it is an important concept because algorithms often need a certain amount of pax for accurate modeling and prediction. For example, if you have a dataset with information about different customers' purchases, each customer would be considered one 'pax'. The more diverse the pax, the better the model can generalize to unseen data.

title: multinomial classification
content: Multinomial Classification is a supervised learning method for predicting which of several possible outcomes will happen, like a multiple-choice test. It works with data where the target has more than two distinct classes. The model learns from labeled examples to classify new instances into one of the predefined categories.

title: tensor shape
content: A tensor shape is the dimensions or size of a tensor in machine learning. It's a list of numbers that shows how many elements are along each dimension (or axis) of the tensor. For example, a 2D tensor with 3 rows and 4 columns has a shape [3, 4]. The concept of tensor shape helps define the structure and layout of data in machine learning models, making computations and operations on tensors more efficient.

title: trajectory
content: A trajectory in Machine Learning refers to a series of states or positions an object goes through over time in a specific space. It helps predict future paths based on past behavior, useful in fields like robotics, finance, and social sciences.

title: self-supervised learning
content: Self-supervised learning is a method in machine learning where models learn from unlabeled data by predicting certain aspects of their input, rather than relying solely on labeled or annotated data. It involves finding related tasks that can be solved using the same data, and then improving performance on the main task through learning these pretext tasks, essentially teaching itself by generating its own supervision signals.

title: chi-square test
content: The chi-square test is a statistical tool to check if there's a significant link between categories in your data. It compares actual counts with what we'd expect if no relationship existed. If the real and expected numbers differ enough, it might mean that the variables are related.

title: mnist
content: MNIST is a popular dataset in machine learning, specifically for image classification tasks. It contains 70,000 grayscale images of handwritten digits (0-9), each being 28x28 pixels. The data is split into 60,000 training samples and 10,000 test samples. MNIST is often used to evaluate the performance of various machine learning algorithms.

title: proxy (sensitive attributes)
content: A "proxy sensitive attribute" in machine learning means a feature that closely relates to a protected, sensitive characteristic (like race, gender, age), but is used instead in the dataset due to ethical or legal reasons. This substitute attribute doesn't directly identify individuals, but can still cause unfair predictions if not handled properly during model training and evaluation.

title: true negative (tn)
content: A "true negative" in machine learning means that the actual outcome is not part of the class, and the model correctly identifies it as such. In simpler words, when the real situation is negative (not belonging to the class), and the model also predicts negativity, this is called a true negative.

title: semi-supervised learning
content: Semi-supervised learning is a machine learning technique that uses both labeled and unlabeled data to enhance model performance. It combines supervised learning (where some data has correct labels) with unlabeled data, which hasn't been categorized yet. The algorithm learns from both types of data: it directly guides itself using the labeled data and identifies patterns in the unlabeled data that can help refine its understanding of the problem domain. This method is particularly useful when obtaining large amounts of labeled data is difficult or time-consuming, as it allows models to learn from a larger dataset overall.

title: hypothesis testing
content: Hypothesis testing is a statistical method in machine learning that checks whether a certain idea (hypothesis) about a population is likely true or not. It involves comparing an actual sample to the expected behavior of a larger group, and deciding if there's enough evidence to reject or accept the hypothesis. This helps us make smart decisions based on data and avoid wrong conclusions.

title: variational autoencoder (vae)
content: A Variational Autoencoder (VAE) is a type of neural network that learns to represent input data in a lower-dimensional latent space while also being able to reconstruct the original input. It does this by using a probabilistic approach, estimating the likelihood of generating the input data based on the learned distribution in the latent space. This allows for better understanding and generation of new, realistic samples from the input data distribution.

title: visualizations
content: Visualizations are pictures or graphics that show data in a way that makes it easier to understand. In machine learning, they help find patterns, trends, and connections within data sets, and also show the results of models or algorithms. They often include charts, graphs, or images that display different parts of the data, like distributions, relationships, or classifications.

title: step size
content: Step size, also called learning rate or step length, is how much an algorithm adjusts its model parameters during each training cycle. It affects how fast or slow a model learns from data and is a vital hyperparameter that can greatly influence the performance of machine learning models. A smaller step size may lead to slower convergence but potentially better accuracy, while a larger step size might result in faster convergence but could also overshoot the optimal solution.

title: root
content: In machine learning, "root" refers to the main part of a decision tree or random forest model. It's where data gets divided into smaller groups based on one important feature and its specific value. The root's job is to choose the most useful feature for splitting, which helps make better predictions.

title: recall
content: In machine learning, recall means how well a classification model can find and return all correct results from a given set of data. It measures the ability to identify all instances of a particular class. A high recall value is good, while a low one suggests missing some instances. Recall, along with precision, are the main evaluation metrics for classification problems.

title: rank (ordinality)
content: In machine learning, "rank" or "ordinality" means the position or order of data points within a dataset based on their values. It categorizes items by size, with each item given a unique number that shows its relative standing compared to others. For example, if we have numbers [3, 5, 1, 4], the rank would be [1, 2, 4, 3] because it represents the order of these values from smallest to largest.

title: training-serving skew
content: Training-Serving Skew is a problem where the data used during a machine learning model's training differs significantly from the real-world data it encounters when deployed. This can lead to poor performance or even failure, as the trained model may not accurately represent the actual data distribution. To address this issue, it's important that the training and serving datasets are similar, or use techniques like data augmentation or online learning to adapt the model to new data distributions.

title: random policy
content: A "random policy" in machine learning means making choices randomly without any specific pattern or rule. This is often used for exploring new states and actions in reinforcement learning algorithms, helping agents discover valuable options over time. It differs from deterministic policies that always choose the same action given a particular state.

title: model
content: A model in machine learning is a way to represent patterns found in data, allowing it to make predictions or decisions. It's like an algorithm that takes input data and turns it into useful results, such as classifying new instances or predicting future outcomes. Models are created using methods like linear regression, decision trees, neural networks, etc., and they get better at what they do by learning from the feedback given during their training process.

title: parameter
content: In simple terms, a parameter in machine learning is a factor that affects how a model behaves or what it produces. It can be a number like the "learning rate" in an algorithm called gradient descent, or a setting chosen by the user before training starts, such as the "number of layers" in a neural network. These parameters help make the model better at its job.

title: confounding variables
content: In machine learning, confounding variables are unintended factors that can affect your model's predictions. These are variables not in your original hypothesis but related to both the dependent and independent variables you study. They can distort the relationship between main variables, leading to incorrect or misleading results. To avoid this, carefully design experiments, control for these factors, or use techniques like randomization or regression adjustment.

title: sketching
content: In machine learning, sketching is a method to simplify complicated mathematical operations or algorithms. It involves replacing these complex processes with simpler, more manageable ones, often using random projections or lower-dimensional representations. This makes computations faster and understanding easier without losing much accuracy.

title: supervised learning
content: Supervised learning is a type of machine learning where algorithms learn from labeled data, meaning each input has a known output. The algorithm is trained using this labeled data to make predictions or decisions for new, unseen inputs. It's called "supervised" because the process involves a teacher (the dataset) guiding the model to learn the correct mapping between inputs and outputs.

title: staged training
content: Staged Training is a method where you break down training a machine learning model into smaller, focused stages or phases. Each stage tackles specific aspects of the model's performance, like overfitting, underfitting, or computational limitations. This approach allows for gradual improvements and fine-tuning by working on smaller parts of data at a time. You evaluate the model's performance after each stage, make adjustments, then move to the next stage. The iterative process ensures that the final model is well-optimized for its intended task.

title: matplotlib
content: Matplotlib is a widely-used Python library that helps create various types of plots and graphs like line charts, scatterplots, histograms, etc., for data visualization. It offers many customization options, making it popular among data scientists and researchers working on Machine Learning projects.

title: prompt
content: A prompt in machine learning is what you give to a model as input. It helps guide the model to make predictions or classifications based on its learned patterns from training data. The prompt can be text, image, or any other form of input, depending on the type of model being used.

title: sensitive attribute
content: A sensitive attribute is a feature in data that could reveal personal or confidential information about individuals if not handled properly. In machine learning, it's important to manage these features carefully to avoid biases and protect privacy. Examples of sensitive attributes are age, race, gender, and medical conditions.

title: recurrent neural network
content: A Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) is a type of neural network that can handle sequential data by considering past inputs while processing new ones. It does this through a looping structure called "recurrent connections" which enables the model to remember and use past information when making predictions or decisions on new input data. This makes RNNs particularly useful for tasks like language translation, speech recognition, and time-series forecasting.

title: novelty detection
content: Novelty Detection is the process of finding patterns or instances in data that differ significantly from what's usually observed within that dataset. It's an unsupervised learning technique where the algorithm learns from the data to recognize and classify new, unusual observations as distinct from typical ones. In simpler terms, it helps identify "outliers" or "anomalies" in your data, which might be important for further investigation or action.

title: tensorflow playground
content: TensorFlow Playground is an online tool that lets you explore machine learning ideas using TensorFlow, a popular library for creating and training neural networks. It has a simple interface where you can visually adjust parts of a neural network, see how they affect the model's performance, and learn about different aspects of machine learning by doing hands-on activities.

title: sparse vector
content: A sparse vector is a way to represent data where most values are zero or very close to zero, but a few important values are not. In machine learning, it helps handle large datasets with many features by only storing the non-zero parts and skipping the rest. This makes calculations faster and uses less memory.

title: ensemble learning
content: Ensemble learning is a technique that combines multiple machine learning models to improve overall performance. It involves training several individual models on the same data set and combining their predictions for more accurate and stable decisions. This approach can help prevent overfitting, increase model stability, and enhance predictive accuracy.

title: token
content: A token, in Machine Learning, represents single pieces of data used for various algorithms. These tokens can be words, numbers, symbols, or images depending on the type of data. In tasks like Natural Language Processing, a sentence is split into individual words (tokens) before analysis. Tokenization helps manage and process large datasets efficiently by treating each token as an independent entity.

title: multitask
content: Multitasking in machine learning means teaching one model to do multiple related tasks at once. This can save time by sharing information between tasks, leading to better performance for each task compared to training separate models individually. It's especially helpful when tasks are connected, as the model can learn from these links and make more accurate predictions.

title: policy
content: A policy in Machine Learning is a set of rules or guidelines for an agent (like an algorithm) to make decisions or take actions within a specific environment. It's like a strategy that tells the agent what action to take based on certain states or conditions. In ML, policies are learned through training and can be represented as mathematical functions or decision-making algorithms.

title: praxis
content: Praxis in Machine Learning means putting learned theories into action. It involves using algorithms, techniques, and models to solve real-world problems by processing data, making predictions, and drawing insights from it. Essentially, praxis is the practical experience of applying machine learning principles to create useful tools and systems.

title: mini-batch stochastic gradient descent
content: Mini-Batch Stochastic Gradient Descent (Mini-Batch SGD) is a popular optimization algorithm in machine learning that updates model parameters iteratively. It combines elements of stochastic gradient descent and mini-batches. In each iteration, it selects a small random subset (mini-batch) from the training data and computes the loss function's gradient with respect to the model's parameters using this subset. Then, it updates the parameters in the direction that minimizes the loss. This process is repeated for multiple passes through the dataset (called epochs). Mini-Batch SGD strikes a balance between the computational efficiency of stochastic methods and the stability of full-batch gradient descent.

title: regression model
content: A regression model is a statistical tool in machine learning that predicts continuous outcomes using one or more input variables. It finds the best-fit line to describe the relationship between these inputs (features) and the output (target variable), enabling accurate predictions when given new data.

title: root mean squared error (rmse)
content: The Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) is a common way to measure how well a machine learning model performs by comparing its predictions with actual values. It calculates the square root of the average of the squared differences between these two sets of numbers, giving one number to judge the model's accuracy. A lower RMSE means better accuracy.

title: training loss
content: Training loss is the gap between a machine learning model's predicted and actual (or desired) values during training. It helps evaluate how well the model learns. The goal is to minimize this loss, meaning predictions should closely match real values. This is usually done by tweaking the model's parameters using an optimization algorithm.

title: validation set
content: A validation set is a smaller part of the main data used in machine learning to check and improve a model's performance during training. It helps avoid overfitting by letting the model learn from the main dataset (training set) while also testing its ability to work with new, unseen data (validation set). The validation set is separate from both the training and test sets, so it doesn't affect the initial learning but still gives useful information about the model's performance.

title: f1 score
content: The F1 score is a widely-used evaluation metric in machine learning that combines precision (the ratio of correct positive predictions) and recall (the ratio of correct positive predictions out of all actual positives). It gives a balanced view of both false positives and false negatives, helping to assess the overall performance of a model. The F1 score ranges from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating better performance.

title: mean
content: The mean, in simple terms, is a way to find the average value in a set of numbers. It's calculated by adding up all the values and then dividing by how many values there are. So, it gives you an idea of what the "typical" or "average" value is in your data.

title: tensorflow
content: TensorFlow is an open-source software library by Google that helps build and train machine learning models. It uses dataflow graphs with tensors (multi-dimensional arrays) for mathematical operations. Efficient on CPUs, GPUs, and TPUs, it's popular due to its flexibility, scalability, and ease of use in various machine learning applications.

title: bias-variance tradeoff
content: In machine learning, the Bias-Variance Tradeoff refers to the challenge of balancing two types of errors: bias (underfitting) and variance (overfitting). A model with high bias oversimplifies data, leading to poor performance on new, unseen data. High variance models fit too closely to training data, resulting in overfitting and poor generalization ability. The goal is to find the right balance between these two errors for better predictive accuracy.

title: scale and feature types
content: Scale refers to the properties of data that can be reduced or transformed without losing information. In machine learning, scale types are either continuous (e.g., age, weight) or categorical (e.g., gender, hair color). Feature types are the specific characteristics used by an algorithm for prediction or classification tasks. They can be numerical (like height or temperature), categorical (like eye color or marital status), or even textual (like product reviews or social media posts).

title: negative sampling
content: Negative sampling is a method used in training neural networks for tasks like language modeling and recommendation systems. It involves choosing some incorrect examples along with the correct ones during training. This helps the model learn better by distinguishing important data from irrelevant ones, improving its ability to generalize and make accurate predictions.

title: regression analysis
content: Regression Analysis is a method in statistics that helps predict relationships between different variables. It shows how changes in one variable affect another. In Machine Learning, it's often used for forecasting or understanding the relationship between dependent and independent variables. The goal is to find the best-fit line (or curve) that describes the data, so we can make predictions on new, unseen data.

title: objective
content: In simple terms, an "objective" in Machine Learning refers to a specific goal or target that a learning algorithm aims to achieve. It is something measurable and quantifiable, like predicting house prices or classifying images. The objective is usually expressed as a mathematical function that the model tries to optimize during training, helping it learn better for future data.

title: spmd
content: SpMD (Single Program, Multiple Data) is a parallel computing method where one program runs across various data sets at once. In machine learning, it helps train models on large datasets by dividing the data into smaller parts and processing them simultaneously, which speeds up the overall process.

title: prediction
content: Prediction is estimating or forecasting what might happen in the future using past information. In machine learning, algorithms learn from old data to make good predictions about new, unseen data. It involves finding connections between different pieces of information (features) and the result they lead to, so the model can make educated guesses for future situations.

title: random forest
content: A Random Forest is an advanced machine learning method that uses many individual Decision Trees to enhance prediction accuracy and reliability. It works by training different sets of trees on various parts of the data, then combining their predictions for a final decision. This process helps avoid overfitting and improves model consistency.

title: prompt tuning
content: Prompt Tuning is the process of adjusting the input text (prompt) given to pre-trained language models like GPT or BERT to improve their performance on specific tasks. This involves changing the prompt's structure, content, or format to better guide the model towards generating more accurate or relevant outputs. Unlike traditional fine-tuning that modifies the model's parameters, prompt tuning focuses solely on optimizing the input text, making it a lightweight and efficient approach for adapting language models to new tasks.

title: rnn
content: A Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) is a type of neural network that works with sequential data by keeping an internal state. This allows it to remember past inputs when processing new ones. It does this through a loop where earlier outputs are fed back into the input at later times, making RNNs especially useful for tasks like natural language processing and speech recognition, as they can identify patterns in sequences of data over time.

title: prior belief
content: In simple terms, "prior belief" in Machine Learning means the initial ideas or estimates about how likely something is, before looking at actual data. It helps start Bayesian methods, which then adjust these beliefs using new evidence from data. So, it's like your educated guess without any data, that gets better as you get more information.

title: sigmoid function
content: A Sigmoid Function is a mathematical tool used in machine learning that transforms any input value into an output between 0 and 1. It has the shape of an "S" or "sigmoid curve," which gives it its name. This function is commonly employed as an activation function within neural networks, especially in logistic regression, where it aids in predicting binary outcomes (like yes/no or true/false) by estimating their probabilities.

title: offline
content: Offline learning means training a machine learning model with a fixed dataset and making predictions based on what it learned from that data. This is different from online learning where the model updates its parameters as new data comes in over time. In offline learning, we evaluate the model's performance using a separate validation or test set that wasn't used during training.

title: state
content: In simple terms, a "state" in Machine Learning refers to the current status or setup of an algorithm, model, or system at any given moment. It includes factors like parameters and variables that affect its behavior and performance. For example, in a neural network, the state could be represented by the values of its weights and biases, which determine how it processes input data. Changing the state can result in different predictions or outcomes from the same model.

title: q-function
content: In simple terms, a "q-function" in Reinforcement Learning is a tool that helps an agent decide what action to take by estimating the best future reward for each situation (state) it encounters. It's used in methods like Q-Learning and others, where it plays a big role in learning the best way for the agent to interact with its environment.

title: uplift modeling
content: Uplift modeling is a method in predictive analytics that estimates the unique impact of an action or intervention on each individual in a dataset. It helps identify which individuals will benefit most from a specific action, like a marketing campaign or policy change, and by how much. This way, it optimizes resource allocation to maximize the overall positive effect for the target population.

title: batch gradient descent
content: Batch Gradient Descent (BGD) is an optimization algorithm in machine learning that minimizes a cost function by adjusting model parameters iteratively. It calculates the gradient of the entire dataset at once, then updates all parameters simultaneously. Unlike Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), which updates after processing one data point or a small batch, BGD can be more computationally expensive but may converge faster due to better gradient estimates.

title: unawareness (to a sensitive attribute)
content: Unawareness to a sensitive attribute means that a model doesn't recognize or use information about a specific characteristic it shouldn't know. This is important in machine learning because models must follow privacy and fairness rules by not using protected details like race, gender, or age when making predictions.

title: numerical data
content: Numerical data refers to information expressed as numbers or values, which can be used for tasks like prediction, classification, and clustering in machine learning. This includes continuous variables (like height, weight, or temperature) and discrete variables (such as age or number of siblings). It's crucial for building models that require numerical calculations, such as linear regression or decision trees.

title: stationarity
content: Stationarity means a time series has consistent statistical properties, such as mean, variance, and autocorrelation, throughout its duration. This implies that patterns and trends in the data do not change with time. It is an important assumption for many machine learning algorithms working on time-series data like ARIMA or LSTM models because it simplifies their assumptions about how the data evolves over time.

title: root directory
content: A root directory is the main folder in a file system where all other folders branch out from. In machine learning (ML), it refers to the primary location for organizing files and subdirectories of an ML project. It serves as a starting point for accessing and managing data, scripts, models, and resources within your project.

title: static
content: In machine learning, "static" means data or variables that don't change during an algorithm's operation. Unlike dynamic data, which can vary over time or based on inputs, static elements stay constant regardless of external factors and keep their values consistently. This is crucial when designing models because it helps maintain consistency and predictability in the results.

title: clustering
content: Clustering is an unsupervised learning method that groups similar data points together based on their features. It finds patterns or structures in a dataset by organizing the data into distinct, coherent clusters. This helps understand relationships between different data points and can be useful for tasks like customer segmentation, image recognition, and anomaly detection.

title: participation bias
content: Participation bias is a type of selection bias in data analysis where people who take part in a study differ significantly from those who don't. This can lead to misleading results, as the sample may not accurately represent the overall population. In machine learning, this issue arises when the training dataset isn't representative of the target population due to unequal participation rates among different groups or demographics.

title: probabilistic regression model
content: A probabilistic regression model is a statistical tool that forecasts continuous outcomes by considering the underlying probability distribution of the target variable. Unlike deterministic models, it accounts for prediction uncertainties by providing a range of possible outputs instead of just one value. This method leads to more precise and reliable predictions, especially when working with noisy or uncertain data.

title: support vector machine (svm)
content: A Support Vector Machine (SVM) is a powerful tool in supervised machine learning, used for both classification and regression tasks. It works by finding the best line or plane (called hyperplane) that separates different data points into distinct classes, maximizing the distance between them. The position and angle of this separating line are determined by the "support vectors" - the most important data points near the decision boundary. SVMs can handle complex, high-dimensional data and excel at solving challenging classification problems.

title: performance
content: Performance in machine learning is how well a model or algorithm does its job. It's usually measured by looking at the accuracy, speed, and reliability of its predictions or decisions. This involves metrics like precision, recall, F1 score, mean squared error, etc., depending on the specific problem being solved. A good model makes correct predictions with few mistakes and can handle new, unseen data well.

title: step
content: A "step" in machine learning refers to a single iteration or phase within an algorithm's process. It's a basic unit of work that contributes to training or prediction. In each step, the model updates its parameters using input data and an optimization method. Tasks like calculating gradients, updating weights, or evaluating performance metrics can be involved. The goal is to gradually improve the model's accuracy by iteratively refining its understanding of the data.

title: data preprocessing
content: Data preprocessing is the process of preparing raw data for use in machine learning algorithms. It involves cleaning, organizing, and scaling the data to improve its quality and make it more meaningful for analysis. Common techniques include handling missing values, dealing with outliers, encoding categorical variables, and standardizing numerical features. The goal is to ensure that the data is consistent, complete, and in a format easily understood by machine learning models, ultimately leading to better model performance.

title: target
content: In simple terms, in machine learning, "target" refers to the outcome or value that a predictive model is trying to learn from input data (features). It's what you want your algorithm to forecast based on the provided dataset. For instance, if you're creating a model to predict house prices, the target would be the price of the house.

title: replica
content: In machine learning, a replica is a copy of an original model (also called "parent" or "master" model). It's made for various reasons like distributed training, parallel processing, or fault tolerance. Having many identical copies lets you do calculations at the same time on different replicas, which speeds up the overall process and improves efficiency.

title: pooling
content: In machine learning, pooling is a technique used to simplify the data from earlier layers in a neural network. It takes a fixed-sized window of information from the previous layer and combines it, usually by averaging or max-pooling, into one value. This helps reduce the amount of data (dimension reduction) and extract more abstract features, which can improve the model's performance and efficiency.

title: confidence intervals
content: In machine learning, confidence intervals are ranges that give a probable range of values for an unknown population parameter with a certain level of certainty. They show how uncertain we are about an estimated value and help us understand the variability in our data, leading to better decisions based on our analysis. By calculating these intervals, we can quantify the precision of our estimates.

title: shard
content: A shard is a divided piece of data in big systems like those used in machine learning. It helps handle large datasets by breaking them into smaller, independent parts that can be processed separately. This improves efficiency and scalability when dealing with huge amounts of data.

title: logistic regression
content: Logistic Regression is a method in machine learning that helps predict whether an event will happen or not within a binary classification problem (like two possible outcomes). It uses a special function called the sigmoid, or logistic, function to change the data into probabilities between 0 and 1. These probabilities can be interpreted as the likelihood of each class. The model learns by adjusting its input weights based on the training data, aiming to make correct predictions for the target variable.

title: offline inference
content: Offline inference is the process of using a pre-trained machine learning model to make predictions or decisions without needing real-time interaction with external data sources. This means that the model has already been trained on a dataset and can now generate predictions based on new input data, independently from any live data streams or connections. It's suitable for scenarios where real-time updates aren't necessary or feasible.

title: out-of-bag evaluation (oob evaluation)
content: Out-of-Bag Evaluation (OOB Evaluation) is a way to measure how well a machine learning model, especially in ensemble methods like Random Forests, works. It does this by using the "out-of-bag" samples - those instances not used when training any individual tree within the forest - as a test set for evaluating the overall model's accuracy. This method gives an unbiased estimate of the model's performance without needing extra data or cross-validation techniques.

title: prompt design
content: Prompt design is creating clear, well-structured questions or statements that guide AI models, especially those using natural language processing (NLP), to generate accurate and relevant responses. It involves designing prompts that elicit specific information from the model while minimizing ambiguity and maximizing clarity. This is essential for effective communication between humans and AI systems in tasks like chatbots or text generation.

title: non-binary condition
content: A "non-binary" concept means having more than just two categories or options in a classification system. In machine learning, this can be useful when dealing with complex data where traditional binary (two-category) models might not accurately represent the problem domain. For example, in sentiment analysis tasks, instead of simply classifying texts as positive or negative, non-binary conditions could involve categorizing them into multiple sentiments like positive, neutral, and negative. This allows for a more nuanced understanding and better model performance.

title: one-hot encoding
content: One-hot encoding is a method in machine learning that transforms categorical variables into binary vectors (0/1). It assigns exactly one 1 and all other elements are 0 for each category, creating new features for every distinct category, making it easier for algorithms to process categorical data.

title: softmax
content: Softmax is a mathematical function used in machine learning that transforms a vector of real numbers into a probability distribution. It ensures the output values are between 0 and 1, with their sum equal to 1. This is crucial for classification tasks involving multiple classes with varying probabilities. The softmax function applies an exponential function to each input value, then divides by the sum of all exponentials, normalizing the results into suitable probabilities.

title: quantization
content: Quantization is a method that lowers the detail (number of bits) used to represent weights and activations in neural network models, while keeping accuracy as much as possible. This process involves changing floating-point values into fixed-point or integer representations, which can greatly reduce the memory usage and computational needs of the model, making it more efficient for use on devices with limited resources like mobile phones or IoT devices.

title: multimodal model
content: A multimodal model is a machine learning algorithm that uses multiple types of input data, like images, text, audio, or sensor readings, to make predictions or generate insights. It combines information from various sources, leading to more complete and accurate results compared to single-source approaches.

title: roc (receiver operating characteristic) curve
content: A Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve is a graph that shows how well a binary classifier performs at different classification thresholds. It plots the True Positive Rate (TPR, also known as Sensitivity or Recall) against the False Positive Rate (FPR, also called 1-Specificity). The TPR is the proportion of actual positives that are correctly identified, while FPR is the proportion of actual negatives incorrectly classified as positive. A perfect classifier would have an ROC curve that follows the top-left corner (TPR=1, FPR=0), whereas a random guesser's ROC curve would follow the diagonal line (TPR=FPR).

title: reinforcement learning (rl)
content: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is a learning method where an agent learns by interacting with its environment. It gets rewards or penalties for its actions, which help it decide better choices in the future. By trying different things, the agent tries to get the most reward overall, and becomes smarter through experience.

title: gradient descent
content: Gradient Descent is a method used in machine learning to find the optimal model parameters by continuously adjusting them in the direction that minimizes the error or "cost" function. Imagine you're on a landscape with hills and valleys, and your goal is to reach the lowest point (the global minimum). The gradient at any given spot shows how steep the slopes are and which way they go. Gradient Descent starts from an initial guess for the parameters and keeps updating them by moving opposite to the gradient (downhill) until it reaches the global minimum, which corresponds to the best set of parameters that minimize the cost function.

title: overfitting
content: Overfitting happens in machine learning when a model learns too much from its training data, including not just patterns but also noise and random fluctuations. This results in poor performance on new, unseen data because the model is overly specialized for the specific training set and struggles to generalize well.

title: decision tree
content: A decision tree is a widely-used machine learning algorithm that organizes decisions and their potential results in a tree shape. It works by repeatedly dividing a dataset into smaller groups based on the most important feature, until each group has similar outcomes. Each branch of the tree represents a decision rule, and the final leaf nodes show the predicted class or value for new data points.

title: weighted sum
content: A weighted sum is a method in machine learning where each input feature gets an importance (weight) that shows how important it is for the target variable. The final result is calculated by multiplying each input with its specific weight, then adding all these products together. This way, the model can focus more or less on certain features based on their assigned weights, helping it make better predictions.

title: zero-shot learning
content: Zero-shot learning is a machine learning method where a model learns to identify or create new ideas it has never seen before, just by being shown their names or descriptions during training. It does this by understanding connections between known and unknown concepts, so the model can apply its knowledge to unseen situations without needing more data for additional training.

title: t5
content: T5 (Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer) is a top-notch language processing model that can handle various text tasks like translation, summarization, and question answering. It uses one unified transformer design to learn from different types of texts, allowing it to adapt to new tasks without needing task-specific adjustments. T5 is built for end-to-end natural language processing, where both input and output are in human-readable formats.

title: pure function
content: A pure function is a concept in math and programming where a function always gives the same output for the same input, without changing external data or introducing randomness. In machine learning, this means that when you call a pure function with the same arguments, it will consistently return the same result, making it easier to understand and troubleshoot your code.

title: packed data
content: Packed data is the process of combining multiple related data points into one smaller representation. This helps in machine learning by saving memory and speeding up calculations. Instead of storing each feature value separately, packed data combines them into a single array or structure, making it easier to handle large datasets.

title: zero-shot prompting
content: Zero-shot prompting is a method in language processing and AI where a trained model can generate responses or outputs for new, unseen tasks just by understanding their descriptions, without needing more training data. It lets the model use its existing knowledge to handle novel situations, allowing it to perform tasks it's never seen before.

title: validation loss
content: Validation loss measures how much a machine learning model's predictions differ from actual values in a separate dataset (validation set). It helps assess the model's performance during training and prevents it from overfitting to the training data. Lower validation loss means better fit of the model on the data.

title: sentiment analysis
content: Sentiment Analysis is a process that identifies and categorizes opinions, feelings, or attitudes in text like social media posts, reviews, or articles. It uses natural language processing and machine learning to analyze the sentiment (positive, negative, or neutral) expressed in the text. This helps businesses understand customer feedback, market trends, and public opinion, allowing them to make informed decisions.

title: optax
content: Optax is a Python library that offers efficient and flexible optimization methods for machine learning models. It provides various optimizers like SGD variants, Adam, RMSprop, etc., along with advanced features such as automatic differentiation, stateful operations, and composable transformations. This makes it easy to create customized optimization algorithms suited for specific tasks or models.

title: tensorflow serving
content: TensorFlow Serving is a versatile, high-speed system that lets you deploy and serve machine learning models built using TensorFlow in real-world settings. It enables real-time predictions by efficiently connecting your apps to trained models, making it ideal for applications like real-time recommendation systems or autonomous vehicles.

title: permutation variable importances
content: Permutation Variable Importance measures how much a machine learning model's accuracy decreases when individual input features (variables) are shuffled or removed. This helps identify which variables are most important for accurate predictions, giving insights into the data and guiding feature selection and optimization processes.

title: optimizer
content: An optimizer is a vital part in machine learning algorithms that efficiently adjusts the model's settings (called weights) during training. Its main goal is to minimize a loss function, which measures how well the model performs on its data. By continuously updating these settings, an optimizer helps the model learn from its errors and improve predictions over time. Common examples are Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), Adam, and RMSProp.

title: single program / multiple data (spmd)
content: SPMD means that many computers do the same task at once, but each one works with a separate set of data. In machine learning, this helps train models on multiple datasets simultaneously, making it quicker and more efficient.

title: t5x
content: T5X is an open-source framework that efficiently trains large Transformer models for natural language processing tasks. It improves upon Google's Transformers library, offering a streamlined environment to train complex models with minimal code changes. T5X simplifies fine-tuning pre-trained models on various tasks, making it popular among NLP researchers and professionals.

title: combinatorics
content: Combinatorics is a math field that focuses on counting, arranging, and combining objects in various ways. In machine learning, it helps with tasks like choosing important features, improving models, and designing efficient algorithms by understanding the possible combinations and their results.

title: structural risk minimization (srm)
content: Structural Risk Minimization (SRM) is a strategy in machine learning that focuses on reducing the chance of overfitting by managing the complexity of a model, like the number of layers or nodes in neural networks. By keeping models simpler, SRM helps ensure learned patterns apply to new, unseen data and not just fit the training data too closely. This often results in better performance with new, unseen data compared to more complex models that have a high risk of overfitting.

title: self-attention (also called self-attention layer)
content: Self-attention is a method in machine learning that enables models to focus on different sections of an input when making predictions. It does this by assigning "weights" or "importance scores" to each part, so the model can pay more attention to the most relevant parts and less to the least important ones. This helps the model understand complex relationships between various parts of the data, improving its ability to make accurate predictions.

title: pr auc (area under the pr curve)
content: PR AUC, or Precision-Recall Area Under the Curve, is a measurement in machine learning that evaluates how well a model balances finding true positive results (precision) with correctly identifying all actual positive cases (recall). It calculates the area under the curve formed by plotting these two values across different classification thresholds. A higher PR AUC means better performance, as it considers both sensitivity in detecting positives and specificity in avoiding false positives.

title: outlier detection
content: Outlier Detection is a process that finds unusual or atypical observations in a dataset which differ significantly from other data points. These anomalies can be due to errors, mislabeling, or rare occurrences. Machine Learning algorithms are often used for this purpose, as they can identify patterns and make predictions based on the majority of data while flagging potential outliers.

title: representation
content: In simple terms, representation in machine learning means changing raw input data into a more understandable format for algorithms to learn from. This transformation involves turning original data into a simpler or abstracted space using techniques like feature extraction or dimensionality reduction. The aim is to highlight important patterns and connections within the data, making it easier for machine learning models to find useful features and make accurate predictions.

title: statistical significance
content: Statistical significance measures whether an observed pattern in a dataset is likely due to chance alone, or if it's a genuine pattern. In machine learning, we often test hypotheses about relationships between variables. If there's less than a 5% chance of observing the same result by chance alone, we say that the finding is statistically significant. This means there's strong evidence to believe the observed effect or relationship is real and not just due to random data variation.

title: sparsity
content: Sparsity in machine learning means that most values in a dataset are close to zero. This is when a matrix or vector has many empty or unimportant entries compared to its total size. It's important for algorithms using dense data structures, as sparse datasets can be processed and stored more efficiently by taking advantage of the zero or near-zero values.

title: loss surface
content: A "loss surface" refers to the graphical representation of a machine learning model's performance during training. It shows how well the model fits the data at different points in its input space. This visual aid helps us understand if the model is improving and guides optimization algorithms to find the best parameters for it. The loss surface can be smooth or bumpy, with local minima (points where the loss decreases in all directions) and a global minimum (the overall lowest loss). The goal is to efficiently navigate this landscape to reach the global minimum, which corresponds to a well-trained model.

title: tpu
content: A TPU (Tensor Processing Unit) is a custom-made hardware created by Google that speeds up tasks in machine learning. It's an ASIC (Application-Specific Integrated Circuit) specifically designed for optimizing deep learning algorithms, making training and inference faster than traditional CPUs or GPUs. TPUs excel at performing matrix operations, which are crucial to many machine learning techniques.

title: plm
content: PLM stands for Pre-trained Language Models, which are advanced techniques in natural language processing (NLP) that use large-scale language datasets to improve various NLP tasks. These models are "pre-trained" on massive text data, enabling them to understand and generate human language more effectively than traditional methods. By fine-tuning these pre-trained models for specific tasks or domains, they can achieve top results with less training data and computational resources compared to training a model from scratch.

title: quantile bucketing
content: Quantile Bucketing is a method in data preprocessing that organizes continuous numerical data into distinct groups, or "buckets," based on their percentiles (quantiles). It involves dividing the range of values into equal or unequal-sized intervals, where each interval represents a specific range. This simplifies complex datasets and makes them more manageable for machine learning algorithms by reducing the dimensionality of continuous features.

title: time series analysis
content: Time Series Analysis is a method that uses statistics to predict patterns or trends from data collected over time.
